151444813.review:
[quote]
[h1] Dishonored 2 | By Wholf[/h1]
[list]
[*] Returning to the main story - it's another point of criticism for me. There are some magnificent aspects; such as the nostalgic callbacks to events in the first Dishonored or reappearances of some of the original game's best characters, but all considered most of the writing is retreading a beaten path. Just as in Dishonored 1, the game flows from mission to mission where the chief objective is simply to eliminate a key player obstructing your path to the throne. This is perfectly fine from a gameplay perspective, but it can lead to a bit of déjà vu from a narrative outlook. Dishonored 2's writing quality isn't poor, but it doesn't distance itself from the comfortable story-staging of its predecessor, making it feel slightly lazy.

[*] On the other side of the same coin, the narrative reactivity of Dishonored 2's world to your choices is truly admirable. Playing DH2 in high chaos; where you murder many people throughout the game, results in huge environmental storytelling changes compared to low chaos. 

[*] Here's an example. If you flood the streets of Karnaca red with blood, subsequent levels show you've harmed the city's inhabitants before you even arrive. Citizens’ moods and perceptions will have soured as they become depressed or monstrous in the wake of their crumbling city - causing suicides and murders to spike throughout Karnaca. And corpses bring bloodflies, which further tarnishes The Jewel of the South in a vicious cycle. You can, of course, avoid all this... by showing a whole lot of care in your actions toward others. Just a little hint ;)

[*] Some of the level designs are really cool and creative, I have three favorite missions and places. I like that there are many ways to deal with enemies – use powers, mines, grenades, sleep darts etc. Another good thing is the freedom in how you play: Be unseen in one mission or let guards ring how many alarms they want. Make people sleep and turn a place into a snoring town. Or go haywire on everyone. Your choice.

[*] It was fun to escape to rooftops or use blink/far reach to get away from enemies and hide somewhere. To tease and confuse an enemy was also fun, by blinking right in front of one and then blink behind their back. Or distract enemies with a copy of yourself. Both Emily and Corvo have great powers. Upgraded Windblast made me feel like Darth Vader blasting enemies into walls. If only Fus Ro Dah would have been this powerful.

[*] Final thoughts, Dishonored 2 is an incredible game that is an absolute 'must-buy' if you enjoyed the original title. It's highly improved, looks amazing, and very in-depth when it comes to skills, ways to kill people, sneak around, hidden/secret places, and... So much more. Unbelievable. I bought it for three euros and boy oh boy. I love every second of it.
[/list]
[/quote]

Can't believe Arkane Studios have gone from making this, to the likes of Redfall and the incredibly inferior Deathloop. Dishonored 2 is a masterpiece of stealth and style set in a stunning steampunk world. 

You can play as either Corvo or Emily - this offers two very different experiences especially in terms of powers and upgrades, as well as choosing either high or low chaos which in itself provides drastically different approaches on top. There is so much gameplay depth and choice here, it is quite remarkable at times.

The fact this is currently 90% off in the autumn sale makes it an essential purchase and I really hope we see Dishonored 3 at some stage with Arkane returning to what they do best. Deathloop 2 = no thanks.

151297189.review:
One of the best first person stealth games out there.

Dishonored rewards you for exploring the world, and allows creative use of your equipment and supernatural abilities to solve the games' missions. It allows for many different viable approaches.
Do you want to be a stealthy assassin who sneaks in, kills their target, and gets back out? Cool. Want to become an unstoppable force, killing everyone and everything in your path? Certainly an option. Want to knock everyone out and put them on a cuddle pile in the streets? Sure.

The game play is great, the story is okay, the setting is cool. Give it a try. You (probably) won't regret it.

151183969.review:
I absolutely LOVED the first Dishonored, I felt it was innovative and the storytelling/atmosphere really immersed you in the game. 

Dishonored 2 still has that, but feels... different. 

While the gameplay is phenomenal and the world building is just as good if not better than the last game, I feel the story was created just so Arkane could make a second game. That being said, it does as great a job as it can to keep you engaged but somehow, throughout my play through, I just had a much harder time being completely invested in it. I did want to see how the game ended, but when It did, I couldn't help but feel a little rushed/underwhelmed. 

What REALLY kept bringing me back is the gameplay mechanics. It is SO FUN darting around the city trying to not raise alarms, find secret passageways and planning for a nonlethal approach all for it to come crashing down by one misplaced dash. I felt fine still though when my stealth approach failed, because the combat alone is incredibly engaging and fun. It doesn't feel drawn out, it doesnt feel like you're slogging through enemies, every gameplay mechanic feels very well balanced. 

TL;DR I do still 100% recommend this game. Although the story feels fabricated just for a second game, It is still engaging enough to want to see it through and the combat is absolutely addicting. PLUS, It is the first game I completed on my Steam Deck and runs GREAT right from startup!

150888484.review:
[b] 8.9/10 [/b]. This sequel not only lives up to the high expectations set by its predecessor but surpasses them in ways that showcase a true evolution in game design. Building upon the foundation of the first game, [i] Dishonored 2 [/i] introduces a host of improvements that elevate the overall experience to new heights.

One of the most notable enhancements is the depth of choice in playstyle. Whether you prefer a stealthy approach or a more aggressive combat style, the game accommodates your decisions with a level of fluidity that is both seamless and gratifying. The expanded array of supernatural abilities adds a layer of creativity to gameplay, allowing for inventive and strategic approaches to each mission.

The narrative is also just as captivating as its predecessor, with a compelling story that unfolds dynamically based on player choices. The dual protagonists, Emily Kaldwin and Corvo Attano, each bring their own unique skills and perspectives to the table, providing a fresh and engaging experience for both newcomers and fans of the series.

However, what truly sets this instalment apart is its vibrant and meticulously crafted environments. From the sun-drenched streets of Karnaca to the eerie grandeur of the Clockwork Mansion, each location feels like a living, breathing entity. The level of detail in the world design is nothing short of remarkable, creating a visually stunning backdrop for the player's adventures.

In all, [i] Dishonored 2 [/i] is an example of how a sequel should evolve and improve upon its predecessor. The enhanced gameplay mechanics, rich narrative, and, most notably, the stunning and vibrant environments make it a must-play for fans of immersive and atmospheric gaming experiences. Arkane Studios has not only met expectations but exceeded them, delivering a game that stands as a testament to the artistry of modern gaming.

150530892.review:
This is a very good stealth game. All in all, a fantastic stealth experience. Going for 100 percent in this game means multiple playthroughs but the game play and story are enough for you to at least play it twice and if you really want the 100 percent a 3rd time with no powers. 
The only thing a bit frustrating about this game is that some achievements require you to do specific things through the whole play through and if you miss those things you are going to be playing the game all over again to try and get them. I've actually beat the game more times than I care to count because of specific achievements. I'm not saying this type of achievement is bad it just becomes extremely tedious after awhile. 
Overall though, for a 2nd game, it's quite good. The story telling is spot on, it's fun to play stealth as well as extremely fun to kill everyone. 
After you're done playing the way the game wants you to play it's rewarding to play how you want to play, the game rewards both well.

150519608.review:
Puntuación: 10/10. Obra maestra. Puede estar fácilmente en mi top 5 de videojuegos.

Trama: Seamos sinceros los guionistas de Dishonored no se comen la cabeza con la premisa. Dishonored 1 dan un golpe contra la emperatriz y te vengas…Dishonored 2 igual pero ahora eliges si ser la emperatriz o sigues siendo el Chad Corvo para acabar con los golpistas. Dicho eso creo que, aunque los objetivos de asesinatos son menos emblemáticos, las misiones y escenarios están mejor diseñados y son mas interesantes. Los mapas son más grandes y hay más maneras de infiltrarse en las ubicaciones.  Bendito al programador que creo el personaje de Delilah y su historia de origen (en referente a eso, creo que el juego se disfruta mas si lo juegas como Emily porque creo que su relación con Delilah es mas personal y desarrollas mas un vinculo de no saber si dice la verdad y sois familia o si miente).

Jugabilidad: Han cogido todas las cosas que funcionaban del 1 y las han mejorado además de meter nuevas mecánicas que a mi gusto son mucho más inmersivas como:
1)Los mercados negros, no solo el hecho de poder comprar y gastar el dinero que recoges de manera mas directa, si no todo ese lore que da a karnaca que te incita a explorar y a buscar las tiendas (y a robarlas).
2)Los soldados mecánicos son extraños, duros y representan una seria amenaza.
3)La misión de viajar en el tiempo y sus efectos…ojalá haber visto más de esa mecánica. Una maravilla de misión.
4)La mansión de jindosh es una obra maestra y un placer visual de principio a fin. 
5)Las moscas de la sangre como sustituto de las ratas de la plaga.
6)El modo sin poderes incrementa la dificultad del juego enormemente.
7)El sistema de caos regresa cosa que no puede faltar en un Dishonored.
8)Muchas más cosas hasta el punto de que podría estar hablando horas de esta saga.
En general Dishonored 2 pule las mecánicas del 1 y agrega más opciones, haciendo que el mundo sea más animado y sus niveles mucho más grandes e inmersivos. Los poderes de Emily me parecen una versión muy interesante de la marca del forastero y creo que se diferencian muy bien de los de Corvo.

Diseño gráfico y sonido: Música y diseño de niveles igual o por encima del 1. Mapas mas grandes y mas variados con mayor cantidad de edificios y me gusta mucho el guiño de la misión final como replicando la misión final del 1. La banda sonora es genial, jugar este juego con auriculares lo hace mucho mejor sin duda.

Opinión personal: Creo que, aunque el Dishonored 1 tiene misiones más emblemáticas pero el 2 es mejor juego en prácticamente todos los aspectos debido a que básicamente pule todas las mecánicas y mejorándolas, dando mayor capacidad de elección al jugador. He echado de menos algo tan icónico como es el Distrito Inundado y Daud y sus balleneros, pero creo que las brujas (sacadas pero mejoradas de los dlcs del 1) suponen un reto igual o incluso mayor.
QUEJA: NO ME GUSTA QUE HAYAN SACADO EL DLC DEATH OUTSIDER COMO UN JUEGO POR SEPARADO. Es un buen dlc y tal pero no me gusta que lo hayan sacado en steam como un juego porque por muy mecanicas nuevas que metas se nota que es un dlc. Dicho eso, deberiais comprar tanto el juego como su dlc. Jugar como Billie Lurk y volver al lado de Daud....increible.

En conclusión: Ta mu bueno.

150475011.review:
I have zero clue why people seem to think this game is worse than the first one, some of the reasons are just absurd like Corvo/Emily being voiced player character, equating to all of the refinements and gameplay changes that people complained about in the first game having been resolved in Dishonored 2 as somehow being a negative. 
not only were just about ALL of your issue's from the first game rectified, combat mechanics have been expanded meaning non-lethal combat amounts to way more than using sleep darts, blinking behind someone or breaking line of sight and then blinking behind a guard to choke them out.

the story has some kinda dull moments but to be perfectly honest and despite what the cult of rose tinted glasses likes to say online, so did the first game and imo this is a much more enjoyable story to work your way through. 
give it a try, especially when it is on sale, just stay away from death of the outsider, there are no redeeming qualities to that release which was originally supposed to be a DLC for Dishonored 2 and unlike DOTO the gameplay and movement in Dishonored 2 is sharp, responsive and carries just enough weight to really make you think about how you're going to both interact with & move through the game world.

lastly: it really is a shame that Arkane has been effectively killed off by Microsoft and because of that we will never see any other games like this nor any additions to the Dishonored story, everything from in game lore, to how some of the achievement descriptions were written out, points to the original dev's from D1 and 2 (which along with 70% of the staff are no longer a part of Arkane Studios) had planned on further expanding this series' story.
what a wild, interesting ride Corvo & Emily's story has been, glad to have experienced it and I hope whoever reads this gets the same level of entertainment and joy from these two games as I have.

150252715.review:
If Dishonored 2 were a dish, it would be a masterful blend of stealth, magic, and a dash of dark humor – served with a side of "Did that just happen?!" The game not only lets you sneak around like a ninja with supernatural powers but also throws in more plot twists than a Shakespearean tragedy.

The game's atmosphere is as moody as a teenager's diary, with a city that looks like it bathed in an oil spill and a sky that's perpetually stuck in a post-apocalyptic sunset. It's like Tim Burton and H.P. Lovecraft had a baby, and Dishonored 2 is the rebellious teenage result.

In conclusion, Dishonored 2 is a must-play for anyone who enjoys a side of wit with their stabby adventures. It's a stealthy ballet of chaos, wrapped in a dark, atmospheric package, and seasoned with enough sass to make even the most hardened assassin crack a smile between murders. Just be prepared for a serious case of teleportation-induced disorientation and a newfound appreciation for sharp objects.

150147219.review:
This person's review is so good, I'm just gunna use it as my own.
---
I'm sad to say that this game was very disappointing especially since I enjoyed the first so much.

I'm not going to hold this one up to the first in the series. I will try to just describe the aspects of the game that make this a NO n my opinion.

The biggest aspect is the scripted enemy behavior which is so transparently scripted (and super buggy) that it very much spoils the gameplay.

Enemies do not continually adapt to their surroundings, something triggers a behavioral script in them and then they start executing that script despite the conditions of the game changing, or even if that action is inappropriate.

Sometimes an enemy will hear a noise at your location and track you down but then get stuck on the stairs or a tree branch and just walk "in the air" permanently. You may be long gone but they are still striding aggressively into open space while their toe is caught on something or they've found their way inside an object they shouldn't be inside.

Enemy sight lines logic is completely broken. You get seen through solid objects for no apparent reason. A great example is enemies at ground level will spot you from hundreds of meters away through gaps in level geometry, even though you're in a closed room on the fourth floor of a building. All of a sudden 6 guards from various directions will all go into swarm mode and run directly up four flights of stairs and through a maze of corridors, opening perfect doors to come and destroy you.

You might take out a pistol in a back alley and blow a guard's head off. A neutral NPC standing within arm's reach will remark "did you hear a gunshot?". Another NPC will walk into the aftermath of a razorwire trap which has completely dismembered a guard, kneel down in the body parts and blood and say "oh no somebody feels unwell!". Or you're walking through a crowded shop area with 5 NPC chilling and one will decide to grab their head and run screaming from you.

And this is what makes the game unplayable. You can be sneaking around, and the broken scripting causes the most insane things to happen at the most unpredictable times.

You might throw a glass to distract an enemy or draw him to an area, but then he gets a pot stuck on his foot and goes mental, running and clanking around. This type of stuff happens constantly, too many to mention! If it was once or twice you could laugh at it and reload, but when every 2nd or 3rd enemy/NPC does something insane, it makes it so you just have to save scum your way through the game if you want to play stealthy.

And the above speaks to the worst part. The utter broken-ness of the game kind of forces you into a violent playstyle if you just want to proceed without frustration. It's actually easy, way too easy to pistol blast, and slash enemies to pieces with your sword. They put an insane amount of effort into making gory decapitation and evisceration animations for some reason. You can pick up decapitated heads and torsos - why? Ugh. I don't mind a bit of cartoony violence in games but this seemed twisted in it's lurid detail.

Other than that this game has all the ingredients you'd be looking for, but it is so broken technically that it's just frustrating.

I really don't like this game and I'm just "hate finishing" it at this point but I refuse to kill any more I don't care how many times I have to reload the same areas.

I am a 52 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing Dishonored 2. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son found this game at Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. Loaded into the game world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Thank you <3

[h1]Dishonored 2 - Best Sequel[/h1]
[quote=The Heart][i] "If we should become parted one day, remember that I know exactly who you are, and that I treasure you." [/i][/quote] 
This games holds a special place in my heart. I remember when they had annouced the game, all the cinematics trailers and hype for the game had me excited.

The story of the game takes places almost 15 years after the events of the first game. It starts in the Castle celebrating the aniversay of Jessamine Kaldwin; where the Duke of Serkonos reveals that Jessamine had an elder sister - Delilah Kaldwin - the rightful Empress. Depending on who you choose, you can either play as Corvo or Emily. An option which I admire that the Game Designer and Developers added was that to refuse the Outsider's Mark. If you accept the Mark, both the playable characters have their own set of unique Powers. If anyone had played the DLC from Dishonored, Delilah Kaldwin is foreshadowed there.

The theme of the game is very much different from the old Victorian era of the first game and is now more vibrant and beautiful on the Karnaca. 

They really have polished and made the game much better. The best part why I really love Dishonored 2 is due to the 2 Missions - Clockwerk Mansion and Crack in the Slab.

[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wsQiKKfKxug] Video Link [/url] I would recommend anyone whose interested in how they made these Levels.

149783734.review:
i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!

"dishonored 2" is the highly-anticipated sequel to the original "dishonored" which was released from developer arkane studios and publisher bethesda in 2012. if you've played the first game, you're familiar with both emily and corvo, and in the sequel you get to play as either corvo or emily (your choice), while in the original game you only played as corvo the entire game. interestingly, arkane initially wanted emily to be the main character, but the decision to include corvo as an optional protagonist came later in development. corvo was silent throughout the entirety of the first game, so early on it was also decided that corvo would be voiced in addition to emily & the NPCs. other adjustments like a harder difficulty, and improved AI being made in response to criticisms of the original. the game was officially announced at E3 2015 during bethesda's presentation to massive hype, mostly around the fact that emily was a playable character. it got a bigger, more in-depth reveal at E3 2016 as well with more polished footage/gameplay, and eventually released in november 2016. 

this sequel offers even more immersion with another great narrative paired with amazing sandbox level design where you can make a variety of choices, each with their own consequences for the entire empire. each mission is a sandbox of possibilities, and the environments are meticulously crafted with multiple paths, secrets, and hidden objectives. there's a mission that takes place in a mansion, and i won't spoil why you're there, but the house can transform and move around and its such an amazing showcase for how great arkane's level-design is. the ability to explore and experiment with different playstyles, whether through stealth or combat, is where the game truly shines. playing a stealth/emily playthrough and going to play a second corvo/lethal playthrough was just a perfect combo, especially paired with their unique abilities. whether you choose to sneak through shadows, summon creatures, or manipulate time, these abilities empower you to approach challenges in your own way as you progress through the political intrigue/supernatural mysteries/moral dilemmas.

some people dislike the art style, but i really enjoy it and i actually respect the fact they didn't go photorealistic or anything different from the original art style. there's really not much to complain about, unless you were expecting something drastically different from what made the 2012 original so great. dishonored 2 is a worthy sequel/successor to the original and is really a masterclass in immersion and player-driven gameplay. i grabbed this in a bundle of all of arkane's games but if you see this for 80% off or more than definitely grab this game because it's definitely at the very least a solid 8/10 (assuming you use the full scale and not give awful games a 6/10). i'm very excited to dive into not only prey (2017), but the standalone game dishonored: death of the outsider, which is more or less a DLC/expansion for dishonored 2 that eventually just became it's own game.

149766164.review:
This one is better than the first to me.

First off, no bugs at all. Kudos to that.

The level design is once again fantastic. You can approach every task in a myriad of ways. There's plenty of places to hide, and plenty of ways to get where you're going.

Blink and Time bend are back. They're as OP as before, and as awesome as before. The time stop they added to blink makes it more fun to traverse quickly. Dark Vision is still sort of doo-doo brown. It still works just fine. The other powers are fun too, but that's where I spent most of my time. 

There's still a myriad of tools to use for combat, and stealth. I did a low chaos run with Corvo. There was no inconsistent detections, and the stealth is solid.

The story was good, as was the last. I enjoyed all the lore you could pick up, and discovering the world of the game.

All in all...solid game all around.

149690819.review:
I stand on the edge of a cliff licked by the waves. The sea is lazy at daybreak, a whaling ship glides by the horizon, and when I turn my head to the left I see Karnaca, a harbor in the shadow of a mountain, like a pair of shark fins. But today I am the shark, and the prey is to become the rebellious duke - one of the conspirators who deprived the young empress Emily Kaldwin of the throne.
I look towards the city from the island on which the duke's opulent residence is located. Fifteen hours ago I was watching an advancing storm front from Addermire Baths and fifteen years ago it was gray clouds from Markham Island Lighthouse.
Back in the present, I set off on a mission that comes close to the cult series on a handshake. The destination awaits me somewhere in the middle of a broken, multi-story level, surrounded by water - and I can jump into that water, I can swim to the rocks, from where I can swing to the gardens at the opposite end of the island, find the entrance to the flooded underground and find myself in the heart of the map, where others will go with dry feet and perhaps even with a bloody sword in hand.

All this without hints and spoilers, which I switched off in the menu, and without magical abilities, which I rejected at the beginning of the game.
At its rawest and purest form, Dishonored 2 is an experience. [b] 60% [/b]

149560671.review:
Like many Bethesda games, it does what it is trying to do well.

If you're looking for a different Bethesda game in this game, you will find homages to those other games, but you will not be satisfied. This game is different, but in a good way.

It utilizes movement in a very interesting and engaging way, and the game changes to suit your play style. 

It's definitely an older game, evident by the lack of NPC awareness. Yes, they will see you, but they'll literally walk on top of the other guard they were just talking to.

If you liked games  back when this came out then you will like this game. If you're a new gamer, who has only played modern titles, I do not recommend going back and playing this game. It's age definitely shows, and while most of the game still carries forward, the lack of NPCs' awareness of one another does not.

Dishonored 2 is a whale of a good time!  It is a sequel that takes place 10ish years later,  Emily Kaldwin gets taken off the throne by a relative and tries to find her way to reclaim it.  You can play as Emily or your old man Corvo, both with a unique set of powers. 

Overall I recommend it!  There are many appearances of characters from the first game, but also many new ones as well! The same can be said about the powers and enemies.  To me Dishonored 2 is like  Avatar 2, it's probably the objectively better in the series, but the first one immersed you with its newness and setting!  I think Dishonored 2's greatest strength is its creativity in its level design and new mechanics, but it never quite reached the cleverness in its storytelling that the first game did.

149115322.review:
This felt much in the spirit of the original Dishonored, but fixed some of the annoying flaws of the first game, things like not being able to do a non-lethal takedown in combat, not being able to refuse the Outsider's mark, and not being able to see during a mission whether you have been observed or have been at fault for a kill. 

Each of the two possible protagonists has access to a slightly different set of powers, and both sets feel appropriately powered.  There's an option that allows you to retain your runes and some other things from a previous playthrough, so you're not feeling the tedium of trying to get runes to the same powers again.   It also lets you use powers from both protagonists, so it feels sort of self-indulgent but in a very fun way.


The settings/locations are really cool and a couple of the missions have a fun twist.  This isn't a terribly long game, but so much thought has gone into the mechanics and lore and there are so many Easter eggs and details to find that it's really a joy to play.  

If I had to nitpick:

Enemies' detection skills scale with difficulty settings, but I wish they were more sensitive/observant at high levels.  

The game retains its predecessor's high vs low-chaos system, but the game is clearly making more distinctions than that.  When I did a kill-everyone playthrough, there were slight differences in the world compared to a more moderate high-chaos run, but that wasn't reflected in the designation.  It seems like it would be nice to have at minimum three levels of chaos label: high, moderate, and low.

148946871.review:
TL;DR Dishonored 2 is a great game, but has a bad story, and you'll see why once the first 2 minutes of the game happen if you've played the first game. If you don't care about the story at all and just want more Dishonored gameplay, this game is good - more than that even, as it refines pretty much every mechanic from Dishonored 1 and has very well made levels to boot. That said though, mind your eyes, because this game has a much brighter palette and environments compared to the darkness of 1, which I personally find jarring at times.

While I would say I like this game, it's really more like a "I like it, but have some criticisms that prevent me from loving it." Particularly with the story. That point and a few others actually prevented me from enjoying this game on my first playthrough a couple of years back, and only recently did I return to it, played it multiple times, and got all the achievements.

I went straight into this game after Dishonored 1, and naturally, I was pretty excited. That excitement pretty much evaporated though once I saw the introduction of the game. Without spoiling anything directly, Daud's entire story got undone in less than two minutes, so if you were a fan of his character and DLC from the first game, this game has bad news for you. 

If you don't mind the introduction being spoiled: [spoiler]Delilah is back like nothing happened, and not only that, she claims to be the sister of Jessamine Kaldwin, therefore she is the rightful empress and Emily isn't. BOOM, you just got DISHONORED. [/spoiler]. And the worst part is, real spoilers for the game this time: [spoiler] It's actually true. Delilah is the half sister of Jessamine, but there just happened to be zero mention or foreshadowing of that in DH1. Okay game, I believe you. [/spoiler] And if you read all that and thought "Wow that sounds stupid," then just wait until you play Death of the Outsider, where it becomes obvious story was definitely on the backburner for this game.

Speaking of the Outsider though, he's back, obviously. But this time he has a new voice, which makes him sound and feel completely different than how he did in DH1. It made me feel like I was talking to his edgier son, rather than the Outsider himself. The Outsider of DH1 made you feel like you were talking to an entity that had thousands of years of knowledge and neither good nor evil, but was nonetheless just observing you in particular because he was curious about what you would do after what happened to you. The Outsider of 2 is a poor man's version at best - like I said before, I feel like I’m talking to his son who’s doing a poor job at imitating his father. And since we’re on the topic, if you want to know another dumb story fact about this game [spoiler] He has a backstory too! That's right, they gave a *god* a backstory on how he became a god...Which I'm pretty sure nobody cared about and was never presented as a mystery in the first game. The Outsider is the Outsider - you didn't need to explain him! Nobody asked! [/spoiler]

Plot stuff aside though, I think it's worth noting that this game distinctly feels different than DH1, and for lack of a better descriptor has a different “vibe" overall. Not a bad thing on its own, but graphics and environment wise, I expected more of the darkness from DH1. That game had a couple of bright environments too, but the difference between 1's occasional brightness and 2's bright environments are the difference between being in a dimly lit room and the sun being directly in your eyes. And when nearly every environment is so bright, you feel much less stealthy. It's a minor thing, and one that probably won't bother you, but I definitely didn't expect it, and to me it felt too different coming straight out of DH1.

Another thing worth noting: A lot of these environments are *way* more crowded than DH1. People actually roam the streets now and are kinda just all over the place. It makes the levels you're in feel alive, but you'll have a much more difficult time seeing and identifying enemies. You could think it's safe to sprint since there's seemingly no enemies around in a crowd of people, but then it turns out you were wrong and there was one or more who just kinda blended in with the crowd. Typically speaking, enemies stick out much less than they did in DH1.

These things aside, I still think this game is worth playing - you have many more options (particularly in the non lethal department) than you did in DH1, movement feels better, level design is crafted in such a way that it takes into account that you may choose to play without powers, and for the most part the powers feel better too (although if you want my advice, play as Corvo first because Emily's Far Reach feels terrible compared to Blink - the former is more like being Spiderman if that interests you over just being able to teleport). Gameplay wise, this game is an improvement over 1 in every way.

Overall, this game is fun. Really fun. But to be blunt, the story reeks of "we need a sequel NOW!" energy, and if you're someone who cares about the story even a little, it'll probably annoy you, especially if you just got finished playing 1 and the Brigmore Witches DLC. Other than that, expect better gameplay, but a different "vibe" compared to the first game.

148516619.review:
I loved dishonored as a game. I actually pre-ordered dishonored 2 back then, not sure what I got for that, it mentioned something about getting stuff but never saw anything. I ended up not gaming anymore for several years and now I've recently started a bit again.

This game was a bit of a disappointment. I don't like having to choose between two protagonists in a game like this. Adding voices was a bit of a turn off for me. I don't really like emily, I don't feel she should be a playable character in the first place, just follow up with more corvo. Overall, this game was a very dull experience mainly because of looting. Having to use night eye 24/7 to try to find the items, trying to gather everything, having to search everywhere for bonecharms and runes... I spent so many hours looting everything and then found out it didn't really matter at all.

There's little consequences of one's actions. What, the heart complains a bit trying to guilt trip you? Maybe some characters mention it in passing? It just felt like it wasn't enough unlike in dishonored where even the weather changed if I recall correctly. 

This kind of feels a bit like hitman in some ways, because you can either just go right ahead and kill the target very fast or skulk around and try to find another way, usually far more vile than simple death despite being the "merciful" option, but there's far less ways to interact with the environment, less options and less to see and do. Because of annoying it is to loot stuff and go everywhere, it takes several times the time to do that compared to just focusing on the main objective and honestly you don't really lose much for it.

The story is decent, but nothing that special. Lots of little snippets of lore and information everywhere but most of them aren't interesting or fun to read.

I guess my main issue is how weird this game felt to play. Either you spend lots of time on nothing or you realize the game is only several hours long with little to see or do other than reading papers. Don't even get me started on the incremental/gradual acceleration or whatever it's called, never played a game with such nauseating gamepad acceleration, it starts very slow and then speeds up more and more, most games does this to some extent to help gamepad users control their aim but this is so heavily overdone that it feels sickening because it disrupts movements completely, I never got used to it, was just barely able to tolerate it and started to try using minimal camera movements so I didn't have to experience that movement curve.

Never felt immersed or truly enjoying it, just barely enough to keep on going, out of a stubbornness to complete what I started more than anything else. I tried a bit of a second run with stealth focus and never being detected and it wasn't much more fun so I quit in the middle after a few hours. Perhaps a full kill, full stealth with dispersion of bodies would be fun. Corvos powers are much more fun than emily's and I played as her the first time, so I guess that's part of why I disliked the game overall. But when you finally start to truly use the powers, you realize you're very restricted by the amount of "mana" potions you have so it becomes less fun.

I'd recommend playing the first game and then playing this but focusing solely on the story, don't get too side-tracked by items or texts, they're just a cheap time sink. You don't really need them to play the game because the game itself is very, very easy even on hard. Play it once and if you're curious about the different endings, watch it on youtube or something.

148514139.review:
The bottom line is, "Dishonored 2 is an excellent and well-made first-person stealth assassination game.“

Dishonored 2 inherits many of the great elements of its previous game(Dishonored, 2012) from its series in general and its overall quality has been improved and elaborated.

While its gameplay has inherited the previous game in general, it has set two playable characters and added several abilities. The graphics are greatly improved, and the overall map design is really good too. Also, the real beauty of this game is that it can be played in various ways depending on gamers’ play-styles. You can be a terrifying assassin through stealth and assassination play, or you can be the best gladiator in the empire who simultaneously exterminates multiple enemies with his/her skills. In addition, there are various equipment and weapons such as knife, pistol, crossbow, grenades, and spring razor etc, making it possible to complete missions in a variety of ways depending on the player's level and play-style.

And its story is really interesting. It was attractive enough to make a story into a novel, such as unique characters, dramatic turns of events, interesting mysteries, and the protagonist who solves them, which greatly contributed to improving players' immersion in the game.

Personally, I think Chapter 4(The Clockwork Mansion) and Chapter 7(A Crack in the Slab) are true masterpieces of this game. They are creative, impressive, and memorable missions that I think deserve a standing ovation if they were a performance. I think they’re the stages that represent this game.

Its soundtracks and background musics are also excellent enough to increase players concentration. I really hope the next game of its series will be released.

In conclusion, as the previous game was a well-made masterpiece too, it is remarkable that Dishonored 2 has inherited its previous game really well. And its quality has been somewhat improved and elaborated. Of course, however, it is a little disappointing that there is nothing new or special creative element compared to its previous title. Nevertheless, it was a better judgment for developers than just receiving negative reviews due to the introduction of a new system.

Stealth is amazing as well combined with the game's power mechanics. I tried my very best to stealth and get the ghost achievement for each of the levels. However the downside to this is that it becomes very disengaging over time. Honestly after achieving complete stealth, it felt as a dis-service to the game for me to do it ever again. Loud or lethal combat is unlike any other, with really cool counter finishers and power abilities. I want to play this game with lethal combat but the game punishes me by giving me a bad ending. 148014162.review:
TL;DR at bottom of review

I bought Dishonored 2, because I thoroughly enjoyed the original game. After finally playing this game, I can say I'm just a little unimpressed. It's a good game, don't get me wrong, but DH2 is undeniably shorter than the first game. The world design, a staple of the original game, felt somehow dated and bland in this sequel. During some missions, I found myself noticing map fragments which were directly lifted from other missions, breaking immersion on a few occasions (and I'm not talking about the black market shops). The story is a bit too predictable, though they definitely tried to improve it by [spoiler] adding branching timelines [/spoiler] and guiding the player through the missions. The issue is that the game oscillates between holding the players hand through every little action and leaving the player wandering for minutes about how to use some poorly-explained game mechanic. Also, I really did not enjoy the way they rebooted the outsiders design and mannerisms. He went from being a mysterious G-man type character to an edgy young adult who never outgrew his goth phase. 

Now that I've finished with my points of contention, I have to sing some praises. Dishonored, as a franchise, has some of the best navigation and level design ever. You really feel like an occult shadow assassin as you explore the limits of this beautiful open world. The fictional world that this game creates is endearing and dynamic, even though the entire game takes place in just two cities. The magic system got a major boost, though I found myself uninterested in most of the new offers, preferring to stick with the old mechanics. The bone charm crafting system was really cool, but I never found a use for it, because by the time I gathered enough bone charms, the game was already over. The option to play as Emily or Corvo is a welcome addition to the game (though I think story works best with Emily as the MC). The higher-level NPC characters, with whom you interact, mostly have good stories to tell.  If you really want to enjoy this game, ready EVERYTHING. There is so much hidden lore and information within documents and books spread throughout the world. My only complaint was that my eyes were hurting by the end of the play through. 

TL;DR Dishonored 2 is a good game. It has a beautiful, expansive world and enjoyable movement system, but often falls flat on aspects like mission flow/continuity. Despite trying to resolve classic Dishonored 1 character storylines, it ultimately fails to leave the player with that lasting feeling of resolution. At the end of this game, you might be left wondering, "huh...is that it?" If you enjoyed Dishonored 1 and find this on sale, you should pick it up and explore the world of Dishonored.

148003239.review: An excellent sneaky game. You can truly play this game entirely without killing anyone and I love it. :D

147991641.review:
Besides the fact that it improves on most aspects, this sequel is very similar to the first game. Perhaps a bit too similar, though. This means it's a very good game, and again I had fun with the mix of stealth and exploration. But it's basically more of the same. Ok, there is the twist that you may play with two characters, which adds... well... even more of the same!

The gameplay in general is also repetivive. You will basically do the same thing from first to last mission (only the seventh brings something new). I played the last two missions mostly to just finish the game, since I was a bit bored by that time. So my little good girl Emily got a bit more murderous and chaotic, and that was a bit refreshing. Perhaps one day I'll do a high-chaos playthrough with Corvo, but unfortunately the game actively punishes you for this kind of gameplay. This goes against the spirit of immersive sims: it gives you the toys, but tells you to not use them. Sure there should be consequences for each kind of playstyle, but also some advantages. The only disadvantage of playing non-lethally is that unconscious enemies can be awakened, but that hapenned just a couple of times in my 40-hour playthrough. Well, Dishonored was always a bit more straightforward, more Thief than Deus Ex. And, in any case,  playing the whole game Rambo-style should also wears down after a while.

I must add something that doesn't seem to be a problem for most, but strongly spoiled my playthrough: a simple and m***nic aesthetic decision to make ALL text and UI interfaces to sway from one side to another, with no option to turn it off (believe, I've dug deep for a solution). It's like reading a book in a boat on rough waters. If you are prone to motion sickness, this makes all text unreadable. Fortunately the game is easy enough that you may just follow objective markers, but you'll have to skip all lore, and so a great part of the immersion goes away. This gives me a new respect for developers that add accessability options to their games.

All in all, given the shortage of immersive sims in the market, it's still a worthy option, but the least interesting Arkane game I played so far. Grab it on a sale, which are frequent and gives hefty discounts.

147844301.review:
It's a recommendation in the context of someone playing the first game and liking it, but Dishonored 2 is fairly impotent. It represents a severe limitation in innovation or creatively. It is borderline a strictly worse version of the first game. 

The original Dishonored had a Spawn, Faustian story. Your wife is murdered, daughter is kidnapped, devil characters gives you super powers to take revenge or set things right. You team up with a cast of characters who act as your support at base; they all have their own goals and ambitions. For what it is, it's a well done story. 

In Dishonered 2, despite being a carbon copy of the original, the story telling is epileptic from the start. There is no game play to establish relationships or let the player make their own conclusions. It just starts with this big bombastic cutscene where evil people that we don't know are doing evil things. . . for some reason. And when I picked the original character from the 1st game to play as, the narrative was clearly not designed for that. They really needed to tweak the opening based on your choice, but that requires work and the result is somewhat laughable with the vilainn knocking you over the head and putting you in a locked room. I'm the guy who single handily saved the kingdom and is extremely lethal. 

From there, things devolve a bit more. You have a base of operations, but it isn't filled with characters. You're pretty much on your own, and while it seemed to hint at building up a sort of crew, that's never really happens. It's just so sparse.

Then we get to the second Mission where I say there just wasn't writing and directing talent involved in the creation of this game. The narrative thrust after the inciting incident may as well have been a completely unrelated side quest. It references to some killer that is framing the main character, but we don't have any relationship to them. We don't know them. The game doesn't even do an adequate job to cement the "framing" as more than rumor. We just have to accept it because the game is insistent on it. And here's where I get on my soap box, because the narrative shifts after two missions to finding your long lost friend who has gone missing in enemy territory. 

THAT is a good place to start the story in earnest. Instead, we're running after a random person who's relationship is unclear, and we only find them by complete happenstance. Wouldn't it have been much more interesting to try and find our friend and along the way stumble upon this conspiracy? The frame work for this game is bumbling incompetence ad naseum. 

And here's where I talk about the game play. Yes it's a carbon copy of the original, BUT the original had some glaring flaws. It was a great game, but it had room to improve; that's why this is so frustrating. Much like Dishonored 2, the original's action and "evil" path was undeveloped. Both games shine when using stealth and finding clever paths and secrets. The violent option is still just a short cut that removes the meat of the content. 

All that's done here is more enemies being thrown at you. If the intent was to force stealth murder play, it fails because the action parts are so easy. And if the goal was to create more of a challenge for the straight forward approach, it fails because it's too easy. 

Does it do anything better? Yes. This game comes through in a big way with two specific levels. I'm not too big of a fan of most of the stages more for reasons of the way they resolve and you are expected to engage with them (the game is arguably more binary in terms of how the missions play out), BUT there are two genuinely jaw dropping levels that are probably worth the price of admission. 

OVERALL, Dishonored 2 is either a lazy or incompetent clone, and I'm not sitting down to follow that blame tree to its roots. As someone who very much enjoyed the first entry, I would have loved to see this take those ideas to the next level or even attempt a step in any direction. 

6/10

147829877.review:
Dishonored 2 nos sumerge una vez más en el oscuro y cautivador mundo de Karnaca, con su intrigante historia y su jugabilidad innovadora. Con una calificación de 8.8/10, esta secuela ha sido aclamada por su narrativa inmersiva y su jugabilidad creativa. Aquí está una revisión detallada del juego:

Gráficos y Diseño Visual (9/10):
El mundo de Karnaca cobra vida con detalles vívidos y una atmósfera envolvente. Los gráficos son impresionantes, con escenarios maravillosamente diseñados y personajes detallados. Los efectos visuales y la iluminación contribuyen significativamente a la inmersión del jugador en este mundo steampunk.

Jugabilidad y Libertad (9/10):
Dishonored 2 se destaca por su enfoque en la libertad del jugador. Ofrece múltiples formas de abordar cada situación, ya sea a través del sigilo, la violencia directa o el uso creativo de las habilidades sobrenaturales de los personajes. La elección de jugar como Emily o Corvo añade una capa adicional de variabilidad, ya que cada uno tiene habilidades únicas que afectan significativamente el estilo de juego.

Historia y Personajes (8/10):
La historia de Dishonored 2 es intrigante y llena de giros inesperados. Los personajes, tanto principales como secundarios, están bien desarrollados y aportan profundidad al mundo del juego. Sin embargo, algunas áreas de la trama podrían haberse explorado más a fondo para proporcionar una experiencia aún más rica.

Rejugabilidad (9/10):
El juego fomenta la rejugabilidad al ofrecer diferentes finales basados en las elecciones del jugador y alentar a los jugadores a experimentar con diferentes estilos de juego y rutas. Además, la posibilidad de desbloquear nuevas habilidades y mejoras proporciona incentivos para jugar de nuevo y explorar diferentes enfoques.

Conclusión:
Dishonored 2 es una secuela sólida que expande y mejora los elementos que hicieron que el primer juego fuera tan apreciado. Con su enfoque en la libertad del jugador y su mundo ricamente detallado, ofrece una experiencia envolvente que sigue desafiando y cautivando a los jugadores incluso después de completar la historia principal.

Calificación: 8.8/10

147449181.review:
[h1]8.5/10[/h1]

[i]There are several reasons I'm rating it slightly lower than D1. It's still an amazing game, just not the successor I hoped it'd be. 

First of all, my problem was the repetitiveness. Only if you play as Emily you can have a little bit different experience, Corvo stays the same even though his mark was taken away and it could easily lead to some new powers, something The Outsider might alter/enhance to help fight against Delilah, but nah—the same 6 options with just a little bit more upgrades, making playing as Corvo feel like it's a big DLC rather than a sequel (even playing as Daud felt different). Then, this problem leads to the next one—the lack of the world's development as the game takes place 15 years after the original story. The technologies are the same: Walls of Light, Arc Pylons, Watchtowers, gunpowder pistols, crossbows, grenades, mines, etc. Yes, the weapons do have more upgrades now, just as the powers do, but is it really the development of 15 in-game years with geniuses like Sokolov and Jindosh? Makes little sense to me. The enemies suffer from the same problem, as all the new types just substitute some of the previous ones: Clockwork Soldiers for Tallboys as the elite enemy type, Howlers for Hatters as the gang enemy type, and Witches for Assassins as... the occasional assassin type? The latter is no particularly different from The Knife of Dunwall and Brightmore Witches, though. Overseers are there but are now more boring (no music boxes). However, what absolutely stunned me was how they introduced Bloodflies as a rat swarm alternative. This feels like a terrible and forced feature in every way: rats were closely connected to the original story, as well as made the Chaos system logical; bloodflies are just a poor copy-paste, partially combined with River Krusts (area-fixed hives with a possibility of loot dropped upon destruction), just because, uhm, well, we had to substitute rats with something, right? I feel like civilians helping or disturbing you based on your Chaos level would be a better choice than a blatant reskin. The story is a major letdown as well, but at least the lore (audiographs, books, and notes) was enjoyable.

But hey, it may be worse than D1 in my book, but there is a thing in D2 that amazed me—those two exact levels I'm confident to call the best in the franchise so far (haven't played DOTO yet). And while I still think that the average consistency of level design is better in D1 (and DLCs), in which every level is almost equally as good, D2 peaked with The Clockwork Mansion and A Crack in the Slab. I also admire the love for details, whether it's [spoiler]the consequences of preventing Aramis Stilton from ruining his life[/spoiler] or [spoiler]finding that iconic secret room from the original.[/spoiler][/i]

TL/DR: It is Dishonored 1 but with another player option (who isn't as fun imo but IS canon so sadly purists like me had to suffer...and were curious)

Almost the same as the first but you can play as Emily OR Corvo (canon option is the former) Takes 11-12 hours casually and 23+ if you can't help but hunt down EVERYTHING (I don't recommend unless you play a personally challenging difficulty since you will need to make use of every little buff. For a casual run though, you can live entirely without any runes or charms honestly.

The Bad: > Emily's powers aren't as fun. Her best one is Domino which links multiple targets fates up to 4 for 1.
>Her version of blink is a shadow hand that pulls you to target which doubles as a enemy grabber (and items though this never worked the 2 times I needed it, mainly used for lethal runs to grab whale juice I guess)
>The ending (Low Chaos for me) is by the book expected and basic and sadly does not explain fates of certain areas you made choices in which must mean they relied on newspapers etc to reveal those but this game is EXHAUSTIVE with text so I started ignoring all that.

The Good: Everything you liked from the first one. Plain and simple. Nothing new except blood flies and no more zombie-like people. For those who like playing games super efficiently and collecting everything and crafting the best buff combos etc, you'll have a ball with the optional bonecharm crafting system (you break them down to single out their ability and then rebuild them with stacked abilities so they only take 1 slot so you can eventually have 4 times more max buffs.)

147199721.review:
Como no se Reseñar juegos aca les dejo la receta de un bizcochuelo casero y esponjoso
Ingredientes para cocinar un bizcochuelo casero (6 personas):

3 huevos

1 taza de aceite neutro

50ml de leche

1 taza de azúcar

2 tazas de harina 0000

1 cucharadita de polvo para hornear

ralladura de 1 limón o esencia de vainilla

azúcar glas

Paso a paso de la preparación: cómo cocinar bizcochuelo casero:

Batir el aceite neutro con el azúcar en un bol hasta que tome una consistencia blanda.

Añadir los 3 huevos. Mezclar muy bien hasta asegurarse de que quede bien incorporado.

Agregar la harina, leche y ralladura del limón/esencia de vainilla. Mezclar durante algunos minutos.

Tomar un molde, enmantecarlo y luego cubrirlo con un poco de harina. Esto es para que el bizcochuelo no se pegue.

Una vez que la mezcla quede homogénea, introducirla en el molde.

Prender el horno en una temperatura de 180º y poner el molde durante 45 minutos, aproximadamente.

Retirar el molde y esperar a que se enfríe durante varios minutos.

Una vez que el molde se termine de enfríar, retirar el bizcochuelo con cuidado.

Espolvorear con azúcar glas la superficie del bizcochuelo.

¡Listo! Ya tenés un fabuloso bizcochuelo casero para comer en familia o con amigos.

146746219.review:
bought this game on my xbox originally (all 3 games actually) and loved them so much I bought them again on my PC. this is one of my favourite games without a doubt, and has been for years!! I'm a huge fan of stealth games and stealth mechanics, and this was the first game that ever introduced me to that concept. 
there's TONS of ways to navigate the missions and different endings you can get based off what you do during those missions (who you kill, special actions, etc). it's a wonderful successor to the first game and improves on both the graphics, content, and mechanics like new powers and an advanced bonecharm/rune crafting system. you can either utilize stealth and spare everyone or just go crazy and kill everyone-- there are traits and powers that suit both routes.
it doesn't shy away from some darker topics including [suicide], [prostitution], and war. there's so much happening in the story, so many things to read and explore that each play-through grants some new insight on the world. 
some might argue that the game itself gets repetitive quickly (you'll put easily 100+ bodies/corpses into various dumpsters and hiding places throughout depending on your stealth) but the different strategies and level design keeps it from being mundane. I've played it countless times and I'm definitely going to play it again and try some new tactics.
overall, wonderful graphics, great story, good voice acting, unique mechanics, and lots of stuff to explore. it came out years ago, but it never feels dated in its graphics or presentation which is why I keep coming back. all in all, 10/10. very much recommend!!!

146695548.review:
I love the Dishonored-franchise, and thus it is easy for me to recommend this title. If you are not appreciative of the first 'Dishonored' though, it may be a different story.
'Dishonored 2' is the follow-up to a surprise success and expectations were high for it, very high. It didn't quite meet these expectations and it wasn't a big commercial success either. The add-on 'Death of the Outsider' is by far the best part this instalment has to offer, and obviously you have to know the whole story to make sense of that final part. So let me break down 'Dishonored 2's strengths and weaknesses.

PRO
- interesting revenge tale, even if a little bit convoluted
- fantastic level design, as Arkane always has (up to 'Deathloop' that is), this alone is actually quite worth the price of admission
- tense atmosphere and world building
- intricate quest design
- varied gameplay offers different solutions to reach your goals
- nice RPG-mechanics
- removing Denuvo (&%$$!!?!!"/&&) really helped the game to run better

NEG
- the game was riddled with technical problems on release, some of them have only been worked around and not really been solved
- vertical gameplay, the first title's strength, has been trimmed down significantly - and this is one of the items which totally escape me
- although Karnaca is very interesting, the change of location has never convinced me
- some of the characters are cartoonish, and the dialogue script is not up to par with the first instalment
- some aspects are re-hashes in new contexts, e.g. the first 'Dishonored' had a rat plague, the second has a bloodfly infestation
- extremely ambitious without totally delivering, i.e. there is some great potential being wasted 

'Dishonored 2' is more of everything its predecessor had to offer. But it comes at the price of watering down the strengths of its predecessor which is a flawless masterpiece. If you like the franchise, it's a no-brainer. Otherwise wait for a sale or check out a 'let's play' first.

146600490.review:
Overall, this game is a solid 8.5+. The artwork, level design and how the powers are designed is brilliant, when everything works the game is absolutely sublime. I would argue that the game is better than the first entry, both gameplay and history wise -even though both stories are very stereotypical, and are mostly saved by their excellent and memorable characters-.

Even with the previously mentioned, the game has some severe issues -although not game breaking- that are quite frustrating and can lead to you stopping playing for a while, and I want to enumerate them just to warn anyone who reads this:

1. Be prepared to reload several times and constantly check your stats if you want to do a  
   no-kill playthrough, as the ragdolls have a tendency to die inexplicably when you aren't even nearby, this has caused me to lose as much as 4 hours of advances once since I wasn't paying attention to my kill stat -since I hadn't killed anyone or even thrown a grenade-.

2. Some puzzles and collectibles are straight up complicated for extending gameplay time and not to fit well into any sort of mind challenge. Examples are: one collectible that requires you to break a wooden plank but ONLY with a crossbow bolt -anything else will NOT break the plank-, many keys that are hidden in random spots in the map, and thus if you find them you can get the collectible, but if you know where the collectible is no clues are given to where to find the keys, one shop rob were you must find a wheel and place it in a place where it doesn't seem to belong, etc. On the other hand, the main history puzzles are well thought and actually require ingenuity to be solved.

3. The game is only half thought for a run with markers disabled (Again, 95% of the cases only related to secondary stuff, not the main questline). By this, I refer to characters telling you to met in X without giving you any indications on where X is, being told to go get some stuff in X without indications, etc. This gets quite annoying sometimes, specially in runs where you don't want to be spotted.

4. The final negative point would be that the AI is worse than in the first entry -the only part where the game performs worse than its predecessor-. Some enemies will go where YOU are when you throw an object that makes sound instead of where the object falls, some enemies will clearly spot you, then run away and lose track of you, some civilians will spot you where you aren't supposed to be and will only get mildly infuriated even tough they should call the guards if you remain X seconds in their LOS, etc. This point might be the least infuriating of them all, but it is annoying nevertheless.

Clearly, the pros outweigh the cons, and by all means this is one of those games that deserves to be bought even without a discount, as it is a masterpiece and time will fly by when you play it, and you will play it more than once, because it has at least 24 paths, albeit realistically with 20 you have already seen everything : Corvo: NO spots, NO kills, powers; Corvo: NO spots, kills, powers; Corvo: spots, kills, powers; Corvo: play normally without going for anything in particular but with powers. Then the same 4 scenarios again but without powers, and then the same 8 previous scenarios but with Emily. Finally, all the previous scenarios but in the NG+ mode. Of course, practically no one is going to play this much, but doing at least 3-4 runs would be normal, as the game has much to offer.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Thank you

145919291.review:
An excellent sequel that improved on the originals mechanics while providing an interesting and solid story continuation. 

The game takes place a number of years after the original and you can play as either Corvo (protagonist from the first game) or Emily (the now Empress you saved in the first game). I have only played as Emily so far, but I am interested to see how different the game is playing as Corvo. The missions feel varied in setting, but kind of repetitive after a while. The stealth mechanics feel good, but combat still feels lacking to me. It's serviceable, but not great. I enjoyed being able to take different approaches to nearly every situation, and exploring the levels was pretty fun. I'm not sure how much of a difference a "High Chaos" vs stealthy playthrough impacts the events in the game, but it does seem to give you different "endings" as far as I could tell. 

I played this entirely on Steamdeck and it ran flawlessly locked at 40fps on Medium settings. Took me about 20h to complete (I explored a lot in each mission). 

Overall, if you liked the first game this is an awesome sequel that made it different enough to feel fresh while not losing what made the first special. Highly recommend the series if you haven't played them.

145905852.review:
I thought this game was really good and a very worthy sequel to the original. The campaign is markedly shorter  but there's definitely potential replay value considering you have two main characters instead of 1. The game also prioritizes stealth still, but there's a lot more opportunity for playing a violent non-stealthy approach, and this approach is even encouraged with a few of the enemy types. No longer, also, is a non-lethal approach truly vital for having a good end-game experience. It's moreso just for bragging rights and achievements, although non-lethal assassinations of the targets definitely changes the epilogue slideshow. It's nothing like the... stuff that Samuel can do in the first game if you aren't a kind individual.

Like all Arkane games there are definitely a variety of approaches to every obstacle, however I definitely disliked how there were multiple sections that were just plain openly linear, such as one area with the clockwork soldiers. I kept exploring expecting to find *something* that could get me around that area but I just didn't find anything and was forced to do it "loud." I really liked the crafting system too.

I think the only real downside to this game is there seemed to be less of a focus on using some of the powers. Blink and dark vision were really the only two I needed, and I only ever "bought" those two plus possession. It didn't seem like I really had to use any of the other powers, and I could even get through a few sections without even using blink.

Title: A Masterpiece of Stealth and Intrigue - My Review of "Dishonored 2"

"Dishonored 2", developed by Arkane Studios and published by Bethesda Softworks, is nothing short of a masterpiece in the realm of stealth-action gaming. As a sequel to the critically acclaimed Dishonored, this game not only lives up to its predecessor's legacy but surpasses it in every way imaginable.

Set in the beautifully crafted, dystopian world of the Empire of the Isles, "Dishonored 2" takes players on an unforgettable journey filled with political intrigue, supernatural powers, and moral choices that leave a lasting impact on the game's richly woven narrative. From the moment you step into this steampunk-inspired world, you're immersed in a breathtakingly detailed and atmospheric setting that feels alive with history and mystery.

One of the game's standout features is its dual protagonist system. Players can choose to take on the role of either Emily Kaldwin, the rightful Empress of the Isles, or Corvo Attano, the protagonist of the first game. Each character offers a unique set of supernatural abilities and play-styles, allowing for diverse approaches to missions and objectives. Emily's powers focus on manipulating time and using shadowy tactics, while Corvo retains his iconic suite of abilities from the first game, enhanced and augmented for even more creative assassinations.

The level design in "Dishonored 2" is a true work of art. Every mission is a mini-masterpiece, with intricately designed environments that offer countless paths, hidden secrets, and alternative routes to achieve your goals. Whether you're navigating the grandiose halls of the Clockwork Mansion, exploring the grimy underbelly of Karnaca, or infiltrating a mysterious cult's compound, the world feels like a living, breathing entity, responding dynamically to your choices.

The heart and soul of "Dishonored 2" is the moral quandary it presents to players. Your choices throughout the game affect not only the narrative but also the world around you. The "chaos" system returns, with your actions determining the fate of the Empire. Will you choose the path of ruthless vengeance, leaving a trail of death and destruction in your wake, or will you opt for a more merciful approach, seeking justice while minimizing collateral damage? The consequences of your decisions are brilliantly reflected in the story's multiple endings, making each play-through a unique experience.

The depth of "Dishonored 2's" game-play mechanics is staggering. The supernatural abilities at your disposal, combined with an arsenal of inventive gadgets and weapons, encourage experimentation and creativity. Whether you're teleporting through time and space, summoning deadly assassins, or using the iconic Blink ability to traverse rooftops and evade enemies, the game-play is a sheer delight for fans of stealth-action.

Visually, "Dishonored 2" is a work of art. The art direction, character designs, and the overall aesthetic are breathtaking. The game runs smoothly and looks stunning even on mid-range hardware, making it accessible to a wide range of players.

The audio design is equally remarkable, with a hauntingly beautiful score that sets the mood perfectly and impeccable voice acting that brings the characters to life. The soundscapes of the Empire of the Isles are filled with the bustling of city streets, eerie whispers of supernatural forces, and the distant cries of seagulls, immersing you completely in the game's world.

In conclusion, "Dishonored 2" is a spectacular triumph of game design, storytelling, and player agency. It offers an immersive experience that rewards creativity, strategic thinking, and moral reflection. Whether you're a fan of stealth games, immersive worlds, or captivating narratives, "Dishonored 2" is an absolute must-play title that stands as a shining example of what the medium can achieve. Dive into its world, make your choices, and discover the true essence of gaming excellence. Arkane Studios has once again proven themselves as masters of their craft, and "Dishonored 2" is a testament to their unwavering commitment to pushing the boundaries of interactive storytelling.

145339212.review:
It's been some time since the last time I wrote a review... Let's make it quick.

Story-wise, it sums up what happened to Corvo and Emily after the story gap between the first game and this one. All the classic powers are here, the new powers are great too, and you can even challenge yourself to play without the abilities if you're a fan of being actually sneaky.

The option to play as either Corvo or Emily brings a new perspective on how they perceive each trial (aka levels/enemies/what have you) in the game. As Corvo, you tend to be a bit more nihilistic towards everything since you're used to what happened in Dishonored 1, whilst Emily tends to be calmer yet sadistical with her approach.

Welp, that's my take, and I definitely can recommend it to anyone looking to relive the experience of being a supernatural assassin.

10/10.

145199474.review:
Dishonored 2 is one of my favorite games, together with the rest of the Dishonored franchise. A few main points that stick out are the dialogue, the level design, music and worldbuilding. 
The dialogue gives the game a character that not many major releases can reproduce. While it is not some cinematic master piece, it perfectly fits the overal theme of the game. I never had a real 'dislike' of any of the characters that was not intended, no characters were annoying. The idle dialogue of a lot of the npc's can also actually be very entertaining. Both main characters also have more dialogue on the current situation then Dishonored one, however Emily Kaldwin certaintly seems more fleshed out in that regard. To me it seems that Emily is made for the first playthrough and Corvo is for a second one.
Arkane Studios has always been amazing at level design, and this does not change. Every problem has 50 ways of approaching it, with the runes only reinforcing this design. My personal strategy was picking people off one by one with Emily's 'grab' ability, however there are truely strategies fit for everyone. Pay close attention to the level, and one might even find a few secret runes and coins. While i skipped a few runes, i am sure that if i put the time in the exploration would not have dissapointed me.
The music is extremely thematic and the game would not be the same without it. The ending credits themes are all in my regular playlists and the ambient songs are on par with Skyrim in quality. I honestly suggest checking out the OST for this game.
Lastly for the upsides, there is the worldbuilding. Through the dialogue of Emily, Corvo and the other characters you learn quite a lot. However the environment teachers you even more about the world of Dishonored. Many hidden rooms have entire stories connected to them, often shown with diary entries, markings on the walls and other environmental things. Another upside is that for the people not interested, this can easily be skipped, however i spent a lot of my time simply reading the letters and notes other people left around.
One MAJOR downside is that the witches and one certain door are infuriating in the pacifist playthrough. The witches are immune to many of your tricks, meaning you have to load a save many times when spotted. The door (TM) you'll know when you see it. There is a riddle connected to it which me and 2 friends spent atleast an hour on before giving up. It is randomised, so a program is needed to decypher it. If you enjoy longwinded riddles then do that, but honestly for many others just look it up online with a decoding program (yes, the community made them for this specific puzzle).
A few other minor gripes include that falldamage seems insane for npc's, meaning i many times had to load saves when i drop them like a meter from a ledge to hide a corpse. However overal the non-pacifist run honestly fixes many problems.

If you enjoyed Dishonored then dishonored 2 is honestly just more of the same with expanded game mechanics. 
It would honestly be a 9/10 if the riddle and the witches did not exist. They simply do not allow me to give it that high, as they taint the last third of the game. The 'time' level also i do not like. Therefor i'll sadly have to lower it to a 7.0
In no way a bad game, however there a few gameplay flaws that taint the pacifist route (In my opinion the 'intended' way to play)

145129650.review:
This is a, short, rushed, and hollow experience. A real disappointment as a follow up to Dishonored 1. The story is "go here, do that" without any twists, turns, revelations. Just when a new mechanic is introduced, (shifting time) and you think the game is hitting its stride, you realize its the penultimate mission. When you see cutscenes having waves unintentionally rolling over a boat and a character while she speaks, you can tell this game was rushed through production. The ending was made in 5 minutes, using only stills, and the choices you made as a result feel like they were pointless decisions because they carried barely any weight to your ending. It amounts to "Oh, and this was a good ending, no detail, no insights, just yeah, well done."
The fighting and game mechanics feel clunkier than the original, and using the bones charms or rune powers feel like they have less importance because you barely notice a difference.

Get this on the cheap when its on sale, but dont expect any where near as satisfying experience as the original game.
