145039617.review: Dishonored 2 is a game that I highly recommend for anyone who enjoys immersive sim, stealth, or action-adventure games. It is a sequel to the critically acclaimed Dishonored, which was released in 2012. Dishonored 2 takes place 15 years after the events of the first game, and lets you choose between playing as Emily Kaldwin, the deposed empress of Dunwall, or Corvo Attano, her father and royal protector. Both characters have their own unique set of supernatural abilities that allow them to manipulate the world and their enemies in creative ways. The game is set in the fictional empire of the Isles, which is inspired by various historical and cultural influences, such as Victorian London, Renaissance Italy, and steampunk aesthetics. The game features a rich and detailed world that reacts to your choices and actions, creating a dynamic and emergent game play experience. You can explore the city of Karnaca, a coastal metropolis that is plagued by corruption, disease, and civil unrest. You can interact with various factions, characters, and environments that will shape your story and your destiny. The game also offers a high level of replay-ability, as you can experiment with different powers, weapons, gadgets, and play-styles. You can choose to be stealthy or aggressive, lethal or non-lethal, chaotic or orderly. The game adapts to your decisions and changes the outcome of the missions and the overall narrative. You can also customize your difficulty level and toggle various options that will affect the game-play and the challenge. Dishonored 2 is a game that delivers on its promise of giving you a lot of freedom and agency in how you approach each situation. It is a game that respects your intelligence and creativity, and rewards you with a satisfying and memorable experience. It is one of the best games of its genre, and one of the best games of all time. The game features a new-game plus mode also, something fans of the first game begged for, as well as a real-time counter of if you were spotted or accidentally killed someone during one of the ghost runs (proper annoying when it says you killed someone at the end of a mission even though you know damn well you didn't, but the game allows you to check this regularly as opposed to the end of the game, so you can just reload the save). One of the most memorable missions in Dishonored 2 is the seventh one, called A Crack in the Slab. In this mission, you travel to the ruined mansion of Aramis Stilton, a former ally who went mad after hosting a seance with your enemies. There, you find a device that lets you travel back and forth between the present and the past, where the mansion is still intact and inhabited by guards and guests. You can use this device to manipulate the environment, bypass obstacles, and alter the course of history. Moreover, the game does this in the Void engine, a game made and managed by Arkane, whilst not losing performance. This is very impressive as the game stacks the two levels (present and past) on top of each other so that you can seamlessly switch between them. This down not drop performance in the slightest, which is impressive to say the least. In short, this game is amazing. It would be a shame not to play it as you would miss out on the lore, atmosphere, music and brand-new abilities introduced into the game.  I implore you, please, play this game. You will not regret it.

144514763.review: Everything that made the first game great has been improved here. Larger and more diverse maps. Clockwork mansion and Stilton's Manor are absolute gems. Between the choices to play as Corvo or Emily, lethal or non-lethal options to deal with enemies, and loud or quiet ways to handle every situation, there are a lot of different possible play styles. The ability to deeply upgrade your powers or not dedicate any runes to powers you're not interested in means you can play exactly the way you most enjoy. This game offers a lot of content. But, its very easy to ignore. On my first playthrough, I solely focused on the main story objectives. I ignored runes, bonecharms, paintings, safes, etc. I didn't like it at all. Years later, I replayed and completed all of the optional side-tasks. Those tasks often led to the most memorable and interesting moments. So, buy it, enjoy the game, and don't forget to take your time. Before you know it, you will have completed every level and be wishing you stopped to smell the roses.

144079051.review:
If you're into gaming that's off-the-charts epic, Dishonored 2 is your jam! Seriously, they took everything that rocked about the first game and cranked it up to eleven.

Let's talk visuals – this game's like a work of art. Karnaca's so detailed, you'll wanna screenshot every corner. Mansions, streets, it's all jaw-dropping. And the story? It's like a rollercoaster of revenge, politics, and crazy supernatural stuff. Emily and Corvo bring their A-game, each with their own powers to unleash havoc or slip past enemies like a boss.

Now the gameplay, whoa! Ever wanted to teleport like a pro? Blink's got you covered. Domino? Link foes and watch 'em drop together. And sneaking? You're a frickin' ghost. Levels are like puzzles waiting for your creative solutions. Sneak, stab, or go wild – your call.

Levels? Open playgrounds. You wanna ninja your way? Do it. Wanna unleash chaos? Have a blast. Dishonored 2's all about choices, dude. And the vibes? Picture steampunk mixed with supernatural eeriness – sets the perfect mood. Soundtrack's like your personal hype crew too.

Dishonored 2 isn't just a game, it's a friggin' experience. If you dig stealth, action, and total gaming awesomeness, do not miss this ride.

144067222.review:
Pros:
*Improved gameplay from Dishonored 1

*Karnaca is a great setting. The world makes up for the lack of decent story.

*Memorable level design/gimmicks (Clockwork Mansion, A Crack in the Slab, Dust District

*2 playable characters with unique powers Emily/Corvo

*New Game+

*Non lethal has many more options now so you can play loud and nonlethal.

*New powers which gives combat more variety.

Cons:
*The game isn't optimized very good so expect performance issues.

*The story isn't anywhere near as good as Dishonored 1. Dishonored 1's story wasn't anything amazing but it had spectacle and there were many memorable characters. This games story is just ok.

*The game forces depth of field every time I reload a save. I had to create a bind to make it stop. Not a huge deal but it gets on my nerves.

Closing Thoughts:
A worthy sequel to Dishonored. The biggest drawback for me is the performance. I have heard that Prey which came out a year later is optimized well. Death of the Outsider which is a standalone expansion to Dishonored 2 runs significantly better as well.

8/10

144005341.review:
Pretty decent sequel to the first, but not better or as good.
As of now I've only played as Emily on loud&high chaos. I plan on replaying some other time. Still, based off of that I would say the game was enjoyable. I think the main thing they did better in this game was the enemies/fighting.

The story was okay. It was good enough to keep me interested, but it lacked the emotion the first game had. I also wasn't interested in any of the side characters.

The gameplay is where I think this game shines. As Emily you get a new set of powers that still allow a stealthy or loud approach. Each level is good at providing multiple routes for any kind of strategy you want to do. There's a few new enemies added, the robotic clockwork soldiers being the most interesting one. I actually really enjoyed fighting them. They were the right of amount of challenging that I felt like I want to avoid them most the time but still interesting enough to not immediately run anytime I engaged with them.

It's a little less optimized and stable than the first. As a low-end PC user I was getting like 40ish fps on the lowest settings. I ran into like no bugs though. People have said it's really buggy but I somehow ran into 0. Idk maybe I just got lucky.

Overall great game. Not as good as the first but still solid and worth full price.

143435569.review:
Regarding the gameplay, the inclusion of the Blink skill has transformed the stealth mechanics, deviating from traditional stealth games and making it somewhat easier to navigate through the game. The NPCs' increased intelligence adds to the challenge, as they can swiftly detect your presence. This balance in difficulty is undeniably one of the game's strengths.

Despite Arkane's creation of a visually stunning world, I regretfully didn't find myself fully immersed in the Dishonored universe. While the game's narrative and environment are captivating, I lacked the motivation to continue with the story, leading me to abandon it after just a few hours of play.

For players who prioritize gameplay over a compelling story, Dishonored may still be a viable option. However, I would advise potential buyers to consider their preferences carefully before making a purchase.

So, there are many things I can say about Dishonored 2, but I think my biggest compliment for the game is that it expanded on what the first game was, and made it better. The biggest critique is that the story is still lacking, it feels very one-note albeit made up for by the amazing worldbuilding.
I don't care too much for the story, but the world you inhabit in the dishonored series is interesting, spooky and fun to learn about.

I'd recommend this to just about anyone, but especially dungeon masters who run roleplaying games. The game is great at teaching you intuitive level design, and the world itself is a perfect place to set a "stealth" campaign in.

143105314.review:
Ive played through this game three times since I bought it about a year ago and completed all the achievements and so its safe to say that this a fun game and a definite recommend to anyone who liked the first game and want something more. 

I think that this game builds on and improves almost everything good about the first game and so its surprising that it hasnt received the same attention which is a shame. Being able to play as either Corvo or Emily was a good choice and having them use different powers was a good choice. It is easily playable in different ways (low or high chaos, weapons or powers, no powers, etc) which adds a lot of choices on how to play. The levels are also really interesting and full of things to find and different paths through the level. The graphics look great even on my mid-tier pc although I was a little disappointed that the art style of the first one was abandoned. The story is fine, it doesnt do anything too interesting but its good enough. 

The only real negatives for me was the fact that the chaos system was heavily watered down from the first game which made the difference in high and low chaos unnoticeable. That was a huge shame as the first game did a good job of changing the world in response to your chaos level and 2 had none of that. If they make a dishonored 3 I hope a better chaos system a la the first game reappears. 

Here is a breakdown of the positives, negatives, and neutrals:

+ Great example of an immersive sim
+ Powers and weapons are fun to use (lots of choices but distinct)
+ Graphics quality is great
+ Improves a lot on Dishonored
+ Fun levels to explore

+/- Story is nothing too special (It has its moments)
+/- Graphics are good but loses out on art style of first game

- Chaos system really watered down from first game, barely notice it

142805574.review:
This game is incredibly satisfying in many diverse ways. You can go about an absolute psychotic rampage of murder and chaos, turning your surroundings into creepily infested ruins, or avoid murder and keep everything nice while possibly challenging yourself to avoid being seen even once the whole game by enemies. The morality system does not lock you either way and you can even shift to the other side mid-game with effort. There are so many different secrets that directly affect your route through the game that even recently I've discovered yet another secret I hadn't found in my 168 previous hours of playing.

Even the achievements are almost all about giving you something new to do in future runs instead of just giving you some daunting or annoying task to take up your time. All in all, I'd say the average player can go through this game over 10 times fully with the intent to explore new things every time and still not see it all. 
From the routes through levels, to the objectives, to the powers and equipment, to the upgrades for them, to the world and its various events that you can witness by just being in the right spot, this game will eat up your free time and you will love every hour of it.
P.S. this goes without saying but I believe every entry in this series is deserving of the same praise and I'd fully recommend the first game, it's 2 dlc stories (which are connected to each other), and Death of the Outsider.

142283416.review:
[h1] Introduction [/h1]

After the release and success of the first part - it would be foolish not to make a sequel. Although the game is no longer new, it still looks fresh and beautiful. After completing the first part - I immediately moved on to the passage of the second and this game exceeded my expectations.

[h1] Main Plot [/h1]

In this part the main opponent is an opponent from first DLC. You are able to choose who you will play for - Corvo (the main character of previous part) or his daughter - princess. In reality it almost doesn’t matter who you will play for, because there is no difference in locations or dialogues. 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

The gameplay in mechanics fully transfer mechanics from first part. The most interesting and new is happening in locations. All locations are new and don’t repeat first part. Arcane Studio worked very well with puzzles, and they are very interesting, the most interesting for me was the puzzle with ladies in different skirts, I spent around an hour to solve it. In one location you need to be in technical palace, where each movement may be seen by the owner. Other palace you need to pass by traveling in time, and places which are closed in past are open in real time.

For those who have seen everything, and do believe, that it will be to easy may chose to play without magic.

[h1] Magic without Outsiders mark [/h1]

[u] Steam Deck [/u]

Many years past since Dishonored 2 has been released, but still games optimization could be much better. As previous part - this game fully has been past in Steam Deck, and this time the load on the hardware was insane, although the decanter doesn't look that outstanding, and even on low settings the game consumed a lot of resources. After playing around with the settings, you can still achieve the desired result and reduce the load on the hardware so that the game does not lose anything in quality and speed. However, it doesn't look like a finished product. But need to tell that I haven’t got any game crash during my gameplay.

[u] FPS issues [/u]

As well need to tell, that there is also a critical bug that underlies this game - if you use FPS lock in system, then be ready, that level may launch for 5-15 minutes. The most interesting, that ingame FPS lock (not in PC system) doesn’t make such problem and all game levels launch very quickly.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

The game looks very good, levels designed very cool, and level innovations are awesome. I enjoyed this part much more then the first Dishonored. Even with all technical issues Dishonored 2 is a good game and I do believe, if you give this game a choice - you may get pleasure from this gameplay.

Pretty much one of the best Stealth games I've ever played.

Great amount of tools and options to both be an undetected ghost and a dark assassin. And the levels. WOW! I would say these are honestly some of the best levels I've played in a stealth game. So many paths to take and viable options for both violent and silent play styles. And all of it wrapped in such striking & interesting visuals. All the praise for the art style in this game. It really is outstanding. Plus the whole mythos the game world plays in is so intriguing. It makes me want to look for side materials to read both in game and out of the game. I'm hoping for a good audiobook with the game's voice actors in them.

As for the overall plot and story, it felt okay. The voice acting, and background lore really elevate it. But I didn't really felt engaged in the story or the characters in it. Maybe one or two characters were great. The rest were okay.

To sum it up, if I was asked for like a hall of fame for games, this will definitely go in there.

142036876.review:
Just finished Dishonored 2. I feel pretty much the same way about it that I feel about Dishonored 1, it's a fantastic stealth/combat game with a decent story outline, and I love how much it gives the player agency over what happens. But it really fumbles hard on the endings. It's so disappointing to play a game for 10 hours and then have essentially a four-slide presentation with some voiceover lines as the denouement. 

I could see a version of Dishonored where there are fully animated and choreographed cutscenes that play out after the game's story ends, sort of like how the beginnings of the games are choreographed cutscenes. You could even have the player interact with people in the epilogue. It just feels hollow to have so little to represent the consequences of your actions, just a picture and some muttered words from a cringey teenage goth god. Because the Outsider is an absolute cringelord, especially in this game. 

7/10 good gameplay bad ending

142020901.review: It’s a great game and everyone who likes stealth games and Dishonored will enjoy it, but overall that’s all it is: just more Dishonored. As far as additions go, that weren’t introduced in the Daud DLC, having two characters does add a lot and encourages replaying the game, also having the Garrett VA voice Corvo is great fanservice. Another addition, clockwork soldiers, are a mixed bag, they are very different from normal enemies and require more elaborate strategies to be dealt with but they can also be extremely annoying especially with their long range 360 degree vision. As far as the levels go there are some that are distinct like the clockwork mansion and the time travel mansion but in general I don’t think most of the levels are very distinguishable from each other or from the levels from the first game, in fact I feel like the levels in Dishonored 1 are more unique in general. Even as someone who wasn’t very invested in the story and lore of Dishonored 1 I can’t deny that the story in Dishonored 2 is worse, they bring back the villain from the Daud DLC which wasn’t even that interesting and make her the antagonist again. There aren’t as many characters at all and even less new ones, and instead of taking place in Dunwall we’re dragged elsewhere despite the start of the game and main goal being to restore the throne, it just feels like all the characters are being dragged through this plot and you’re also there. My biggest problem with this game is that it simply doesn’t improve on the previous game’s formula enough, any criticism related to lack of incentive to engage meaningfully with the sandbox still applies to this game, and enemies, mechanics, even level design remain largely the same.

141927018.review:
[h1]Likes[/h1]

[b]Discovery[/b]
The game, as immersive sims tend to do, features a whole bunch of obscure interactions that you'll have to discover for yourself; the game keeps you in the constant state of asking "what if". Most of the time, the "what if" ideas don't pan out, but when they do, you'll feel clever for discovering them, and this fuels you to keep experimenting.

[b]Art direction[/b]
The same familiar art style from the first game returns here with a tropical twist. Gone are the dull industrial colors and depressing mood of Dunwall. Some people lament the missing dystopic atmosphere of Dunwall, but I don't think that's necessarily a problem. Things aren't exactly looking up in Karnaca either, it's dystopic in a different way.

[b]Voiced protagonist[/b]
Not particularly a high bar to cross, but I preferred the voiced protagonists to the first game's silent Corvo. The protagonist commenting on the surroundings was a nice subtle way to introduce lore and personality to the environment, and since there are two possible characters to pick from, you'll get multiple perspectives.


[h1]Gripes[/h1]

[b]Ending[/b]
The ending of the game was disappointing. The post-campaign summary is very short, about 2-4 Powerpoint slides long. Don't get me wrong, the slide presentation is nice and all, but I would've preferred more slides summarizing my actions and their results, even if the visual quality would've been lesser for it.

[b]Voiced protagonist[/b]
There are oftentimes situations where I would expect the protagonist to comment on something because it's related to them, but they don't. I wonder if this is a budget problem caused by having two protagonists.

[b]No neutrality[/b]
I wish that the game had a middle ground option between the two extreme playstyles: the pacifist assassin or the complete murderhobo. You [b][i]can[/i][/b] play through the game with a medium chaos playstyle, but due to it not being an [b][i]actual[/i][/b] option, your character's personality ends up bouncing between a sociopath and an empath. The strangest thing is that the game features a device capable of discerning if a person is despicable or not, as if encouraging stabbing of some and showing restraint for others.

[b]Non-lethal combat[/b]
The murderhobo playthrough is perfect in its current form, it's fast, visceral, flashy and most importantly, fun. When you inevitably get spotted in the middle of your murder spree, you can just smoothly transition from a venomous snake to a feral tiger, in contrast, a non-lethal player might prefer to just reload a previous save due to the enormous risk of collateral damage in melee combat. It [b][i]is[/i][/b] possible to do non-lethal combat but it's clunky. Most things that prime enemies to be knocked out can also cause their deaths, not to mention the enemies' complete disregard for their colleague's lives. Most of my collateral kills can be attributed to enemies stabbing each other.

141881835.review:
Dishonored 2 - 7/10 

NOTICE: This game is optimized like a turd. It runs incredibly badly, and is vulnerable to crashes. You either need a super computer, or you have to just suck it up and play on the lowest settings, along with a lowered resolution as well. 

Completed as Emily on Non-Lethal

This game is both blessed and cursed. On one hand, it's a massive improvement over the first game. On the other, it has its own bag of bullsht. 

The story, characters, world, and level design, are all incredibly good, it's a lot more alive and more realistic than before (for a fictional setting with magical powers, I mean it's more believable in this world). The powers you have (as Emily) are much better than in Dishonored 1, far more useful and interesting that make the game better to play, and depending on what you choose to get, it changes the way you think and play the game.

However, when it comes to being non-lethal, the game feels like it does everything in its power to prevent it. When you're holding an NPC and trying to choke them out, other NPCs don't give a single sht and will slash at you with their swords or shoot you with their guns. Then, they'll kill the person you're holding, and for SOME REASON the game thinks YOU'RE responsible for their death. NO I AM NOT. I did not in any way, shape, or form, kill that person, and I have no reason to be punished for it. I've had to load my saves so, so many times, because enemies kept killing their friends, and I was the one punished for their deaths. I've even had to restart entire missions, twice, because I had no save file back to before I "killed" people. 

I also find it's often a bit too difficult to escape once you've been seen (in some cases, too easy). I had the bonecharm that makes you invisible when using Blink/Far Reach, but people occasionally still saw me. Using Dark Vision, I can see where people are looking. I STILL got seen by enemies WHEN THEY AREN'T EVEN LOOKING IN MY DIRECTION! WHY?! Oh, also, blueprints for upgrades aren't visible in Dark Vision for some reason and I missed so many.

They made non-lethal play a lot more fun, but also made it a massive pain to do at the same time. Most likely more enjoyable to go lethal. Overall, I'd say this game is worth it if you think you can deal with its glaring faults.

Edit: 

Oh, yeah, and every time I start up the game, I have to sit on a loading screen for around 4 minutes 30 seconds. EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. I START THE GAME.

141501487.review:
improves on every single aspect of the first game (which was already almost perfect) EXCEPT:
-the outsider's new voice is bad, the previous one was way better but he doesn't appear for more than a couple minutes every now and then therefore it's not a big issue
-voiced protagonists have verry little nuance to them, they mainly explain what is going on around them and sometimes TRY to emote but mostly fail since every characther in these games is really monotonous; the silent protagonist of D1 was more fitting to the theme and easier to relate to; the protagonist of the D1 DLCs, Daud, only narrated the beginning of the levels and responded to dialogue, was easier to cope with since he was an already established person in the game's world with pre-determined motives and thoughts
-after a basic understanding of the game mechanics, it becomes really easy even on the hardest difficulty; your character becomes overpowered after a couple of hours and even that is redundant since most of the game can be completed by blinking across rooftops and shooting your mission targets from a distance; i would have appreciated the higher difficulties being more populated by obstructions (guards, devices that try to stop you etc.)
-the main thread of the plot feels a bit stretched, i will not go into detail due to spoilers but don't go into the game expecting to be blown away by twists and turns of the narrative, the game doesn't have those, and the ending is EXACTLY what you would expect after playing the game, no surprises there either, and it is mostly a setup for a secondary character that will show up in the DLC/expansion

Even tho the flaws that i listed take up a lot of space (which is only because i wanted to explain them thoroughly), they don't take away much from the basic dishonored experience: supernatural assasin! the game is a lot of fun and has multiple paths to take, decisions to think about that matter, huge levels to explore, and many enemies to kill ( or avoid! ) in creative ways. Good game, don't miss it!

Dishonored 2 is a good game. It improves upon the first on what concerns graphics, environment and gameplay. It plays nicely, both weapons and magic. The new enemy types are good additions -- the bugs, the robots, the witches. Playing as Emily is unquestionably very cool. And an honorable mention should be made to the mission that takes place in the mansion and involves time travel -- super clever design that every review would be remiss to not mention.

However... The game is definitely weaker as far as the story is concerned. Dishonored 1 had a very strong and tight story. The story in the sequel is simply not as appealing, as the assassination targets don't feel as interesting. The biggest issue is the main villain, for me personally it was difficult to find them threatening or be invested in their inevitable downfall.


Verdict: despite the gameplay/story tradeoff, it's still worth playing.

141229652.review:
This version of dishonoured takes place 20-ish years later and still has the optional harmless approach to neutralising targets which I enjoy. The mechanics have more depth i.e you can now move while strangling guards (I never remember doing this in the first but maybe I missed it), and the maps have some INSANE mechanics. One map has rooms that move horizontally and vertically to swap locations with other rooms making the map half a moving puzzle; and another map has a time swap-er item so you need to swap between the current destroyed version of the map and the past mint condition version of the map to avoid being caught and get to locations. Props also have more accurate "vision boxes" so you are no longer safe behind railings, glass doors, and windows that are 1 foot off the ground. The power system is more expansive than the first, but it is a combination of new and breaking the previous powers down into smaller upgrade-able powers which I find more convoluted. Also, rat tunnels/vents seem almost useless now which just limits the possibilities of completing missions.
There were also objectives which required searching a room for evidence which is boring and can end up with you leaving empty handed and frustrated because you didn't see a brown leather book on the ground under an unlit table on brown wood floors.
The maps are bigger and thus the missions are longer (2-3 hours) and I found myself having to continue the missions in another play session where I forgot parts of the story. The maps can be difficult to navigate especially when it's your first time playing it, and this time you can choose to be no magic so there are paths to complete the mission without magic and if you happen to chose to infiltrate through this path it ends up being boring because there isn't much use for magic. In addition, the multiple paths to infiltrate are more secretive this time around i.e 1 window on the side of a building.
Ending is extremely mediocre, short, and very similar to the first game's ending. There are many endings, but the differences are minor, all that matters is if you finished with low or high chaos.
Overall, they made the game systems, mechanics, and maps have more depth which just made the game harder and convoluted, but the cool map mechanics were a great addition. I just really like Dishonored so you should still play it (but the first one is better; well refined and less gimmicky).

140987791.review:
An Exemplary Sequel Painting A Vivid Picture of Choice and Consequence"

Rating: ★★★★★

The shadowy elegance of the Dishonored series took a triumphant leap forward with the release of Dishonored 2 in 2016. A masterclass in interactive storytelling, level design, and strategic gameplay, Dishonored 2 immerses you into its captivating world of intrigue and supernatural skullduggery with an effortless grace that is hard to come by in gaming today.

What makes Dishonored 2 such a standout sequel is its commitment to player choice. As either Emily Kaldwin, the dethroned empress, or Corvo Attano, the grizzled royal protector from the original game, you are gifted with a wide array of supernatural abilities and tools. Each character brings a unique flavor to the gameplay. Corvo's experienced and methodical approach contrasts perfectly with Emily's innovative and fluid style.

The real superstar of Dishonored 2, however, is its level design. Take, for instance, the Clockwork Mansion, a shifting, mechanical labyrinth that's as much a character as any human or supernatural being you'll encounter. It's a magnificent feat of design, its various moving parts and secret pathways serving to emphasize the game's central theme of hidden truths beneath polished exteriors.

Another standout is the time-bending mission, A Crack in the Slab, where you're stripped of your powers and given a device that lets you traverse between the past and the present. It's a stunning example of the game's ability to challenge you to think creatively about your environment.

In terms of narrative, Dishonored 2 enhances the lore of the world introduced in the first game. The power struggle in Dunwall and the political maneuverings in Karnaca provide a textured backdrop against which the personal stories of Corvo and Emily unfold. Moreover, the introduction of new antagonist Delilah Copperspoon adds a fresh dynamic and a worthy adversary to the mix.

The morality system, another pivotal aspect of Dishonored 2, heightens the sense of player agency. Every decision has consequences, every action repercussions. The game constantly reminds you that you're an influential actor in a living, breathing world.

Visually, the game is stunning. The world of Dishonored 2 is a blend of grimy reality and dreamy, painterly aesthetics. Whether it's the cold, dark streets of Dunwall or the sun-drenched, decaying beauty of Karnaca, every location is meticulously detailed and beautifully rendered.

With its deep, rewarding gameplay, Dishonored 2 is not just a worthy successor to its groundbreaking predecessor but also an exceptional game in its own right. It takes everything that made the original game a standout, fine-tunes it, and adds layers of depth and complexity. Dishonored 2 is a testament to the creative power of video games as a medium and a must-play for any fan of the stealth-action genre.

140929719.review:
7,5/10

Dishonored 2 is very much a sequel of the "more of the same" variety. The narrative is extended and there are more variations of enemies, abilities and mechanics, but the core feels like it was carried over straght from the first game. For the most part that isn't a bad thing, but I would have liked to see some overhauls to the formula. 

The stealth in this series has a few fatal flaws that takes away from what could have been one of the most solid franchises ever made. The issue here stems from how the game handles the two binary paths of its narrative, where killing enemies puts you on the "bad" path, and sparing them puts you on the "good" path. This means that if you are ever caught while sneaking, you have the choice of killing your attackers and going down the "bad" path, or evading them and going down the "good" path. The enemies are very easy to deal with either way, due in equal measure to the abilities you have, and to their incompetence.

If you want the narrative to go in the "good" direction, fighting is not a viable option, taking with it a majority of the skills and gadgets in the game. Instead, your only option is to evade them, which then leads to long stretches of waiting in the rafters for the guards to give up looking for you so that you can continue the game. There is no tension in this, neither in avoiding detection or in evading the enemy once you've been detected. The fact that you have such overpowered abilites has also caused the enemy placement and behaviour to become more frustrating than engaging in order to try and offer you some challenge, meaning that more traditional stealth gameplay just isn't viable, and instead I ended up feeling like I was supposed to glitch the teleportation skill in order to overcome the challenge. It's quite the mess, really.

The only path that offers some inherent value is the violent one, since you then get to play around with the abilities and gadgets, but the game then instead becomes a violent power fantasy, which really isn't what I'm playing this game for, and the narrative punishes you for it.

For any other franchise, these things would have meant that I would stop playing the game fairly early on, and definitely not spend close to 100 hundred hours across all the installments, but Dihonored is so amazingly good in all other aspects, that I can deal with the fundamental shortcomings of its core gameplay in order to experience it.

The world building is just simply top notch. The level design, the art, the environmental storytelling, the atmosphere, the writing, the characters, the side stories - all of it is so utterly enthralling that it overcomes the kind of flaws to its most fundamental gameplay core that would have been fatal to any other franchise. That was true for the first game, and it is equally true here.

140683200.review:
After having played the first instalment, I waited quite some time before playing this sequel. I waited for it to be on special after reading poor reviews of it but honestly, I think it is much better than the first. While the story does continue from the first, it is sufficiently standalone to not require any prior knowledge or game play.

The main thing I look for in a first/third person game is playability / how fun is it to manoeuvre and achieve your tasks. This game has it in spades as you are able to climb and interact through well designed levels which are technically fairly linear but never feel that way. 

You are able to play the game entirely without special abilities, though why would you for anything other than a repeat play-through for achievements, as this is quite personally the most enjoyable and unique aspect of the game. Without them it's just another stealth game set in a steampunk industrial Elizabethan dystopia. 

Lastly, I'm no longer a huge fan of stealth games where most of your time is spent figuring out patrol routes and timings. This is very forgiving and never feels tedious so I can comfortably enjoy the stealth route. That being said, the darker route is fairly satisfying, despite the clear warnings that it would result in a darker ending. If you aren't one for caring about the plot, or ending, then get slashing for a giggle.

Good job Bethesda.

140614572.review:
Simulate Stealthy Shennanigans: Dishonored 2 doubles as a simulation for the truly paranoid. Can't go outside without imagining assassins around every corner? Dishonored 2 not only validates your fears, it turns them into an interactive playground!

Pigeon Simulator: Tired of being human? Dishonored 2’s ‘Possession’ skill lets you become a pigeon, a rat, or a fish, giving you a whole new perspective on life. Heck, you might even prefer it to your 9-to-5!

Who Needs Therapy: Dishonored 2 helps you work through your daddy-daughter issues vicariously. After all, it's cheaper than therapy, and you can stealth-kill some enemies to vent out any residual frustration!

Give Corvo a Voice: Remember Corvo from the first game? The silent protagonist who let his actions do the talking? Well, Dishonored 2 gave him a voice, and boy does he have things to say! It's a talking simulator, too. Can't get enough of those, can you?

Interior Design: The game is an inspiration for Gothic home design enthusiasts. Just think of the locations as a 3D interactive IKEA catalog for the dramatically inclined. Who doesn't want chandeliers shaped like tentacled horrors?

Ghost Run for Cowards: If you're like me and can't bear the guilt of killing virtual characters, Dishonored 2 offers you the 'Ghost' mode, where you can skulk around and finish the game without spilling a single drop of blood. Chicken-hearted escapism has never been so rewarding!

Clockwork Mansion: Forget about haunted houses, the real nightmare is a house that rearranges itself. It's an exercise in both survival and remembering where you left your keys. Bonus: you get to dismantle your own homicidal Roombas!

Affection for Afflictions: The game lets you turn people to dust, summon rats to do your bidding, or link destinies of several folks and make them share the same fate. It's like being in a particularly gruesome nursery rhyme.

Get Lost in Karnaca: Dishonored 2's city, Karnaca, is beautifully designed. You'll get lost more often than you'd like to admit. It's like a trip to a foreign city, but without the expensive plane tickets, and with significantly more murderers.

Whalepunk Aesthetics: Lastly, you'll be playing Dishonored 2 for its unique "whalepunk" aesthetics. Ever wondered what it would be like if whales were the primary source of power in a dystopian Victorian era? No? Well, you're going to find out anyway!

Overall, Dishonored 2 is a riot of a game that blends the brutal and the absurd, served on a platter of stunning aesthetics and layered narrative. Whether you're a fan of stealth games, dark fantasy, or you just love a good laugh, this game is a must-play. Happy sneaking, friends!

140545984.review:
[h1]Dishonored 2[/h1]
I like the Dishonored series, I went through the first part many times. It is a very good game with a lot of freedom. The second one is not inferior to the previous one, it has even more content. More ways to complete missions, more playable characters, more skills, more equipment, etc. It was a pretty solid game for 2016. 

 [b] [u]Storyline [/u] [/b]

I want to start with [b]the most controversial[/b] element, the story. In my opinion, the main storyline is less interesting than in the first part. There are no twists and turns, and the main reason for our journey is very similar to the one in the previous part.

 [b]You will not see any character development or disputes in the group[/b]. Your hub (ship) is very empty, with literally only two allies on it. If you compare this to the first Dishonored, when you had a lot of talkative people reacting to your actions, it's a step backwards.

 [b]But it's not all bad[/b], perhaps the reason for the journey is very similar, but that doesn't mean it's not interesting. The new villains are very interesting with their skeletons in the closet. There is a lot of readable material in each area that explains each enemy's story and why they do it. Many optional dialogues between npc also contain useful information. 

 [b]In brief[/b], the main plot and main characters are not very interesting. The lack of character development and the emptiness of the allied forces make me feel sad. But the villains are more interesting than even in the first part, many of them have their own reasons and their own style, which makes them unforgettable.

 [b] [u]Gameplay[/u] [/b]

[b]As I said, you have more stuff now than you had in the first part[/b]. First, there are two playable characters, Corvo and Emily. Character selection affects some of the dialogue and cutscenes, but the overall effect in the storyline is minor. However in the gameplay, you have a bunch of different skills for each character, which makes your playthrough varied.

[b]The next big gameplay update is the variety of everything in the levels[/b]. There was a lot of variety in the first part, but now it's just crazy. There are a lot of ways to complete quests: you can just go through all enemies with a fair fight [i](1 vs n → inf)[/i], you can stealthily kill all enemies or just walk by, you can help some npc with their quests, and they will help you in return, you can just stop time and also walk by, etc. And such variety in everything. For example, all the black markets can be robbed, of course, if you find a way how, and each shop has its own methods of robbery. The levels are just interesting to explore. 

[b]The enemy AI[/b] is also very good [i](for a video game)[/i], they communicate with each other, have different levels of alertness, and hostile factions fight each other. They can react to certain player actions, such as opening doors, turning off electricity, etc. This makes the stealth gameplay unique. 

The game contains a [b]"Chaos Level"[/b], it is determined by your actions, if you create a lot of noise, kill a lot of people, the level will increase. As a result, the locations will change, there will be more common enemies and bloodflies, more empty buildings, and it will affect the game's ending.

 [b] [u]Environment[/u] [/b]

[b]Very great attention to detail[/b]. Each level has many details that describe the lore, the plot of the game. You can get information from books/notes, listening to npc, looking around. Even when you need, for example, the code for the safe, it turns into a mini-game where you read all the notes, look at every picture, and press all the buttons. But it doesn't get boring, the environments are really well-designed and original.

[b]There are many secrets[/b] that are hidden in different parts of the map. They can captivate you for more than one hour. The game also generously rewards you for finding secrets.

 [b] [u]Conclusion[/u] [/b]

I really like this game, I’ve passed it 3 times and never got bored. The great variation in the game makes me try something new every time. I recommend playing this game at least twice for each character, and playing the first time in stealth mode, trying to make as little noise and killing as possible. And in the new game+ try playing as a slayer machine. Such a contrast will evoke pleasant emotions. 

 [b] [u]Score: 4uсking S[/u] [/b]

140452390.review:
Dishonored 2 is a stunning sequel that improves on almost every aspect of the original game. It offers you a choice between two protagonists, each with their own unique abilities and perspectives, and lets you explore a rich and immersive world full of secrets, challenges, and consequences. Whether you prefer stealth or combat, lethal or non-lethal, Dishonored 2 gives you the freedom and tools to play your way.

The game takes place in the city of Karnaca, a beautiful and exotic location that contrasts with the grimy and oppressive Dunwall from the first game. The city is alive with detail and diversity, from the dusty streets and slums to the lavish mansions and gardens. The game also features some of the most creative and memorable missions in the genre, such as a clockwork mansion that changes its layout at the flip of a switch, or a time-travel device that lets you switch between two different eras of the same location.

The gameplay is smooth and satisfying, with responsive controls and fluid animations. The combat is brutal and visceral, with a variety of weapons and gadgets to use against your enemies. The stealth is tense and rewarding, with multiple paths and options to avoid detection or neutralize threats. The powers are fun and versatile, allowing you to manipulate the environment and your foes in various ways. You can also customize your powers and playstyle with bonecharms and upgrades, or even challenge yourself by rejecting the supernatural gifts altogether.

Dishonored 2 is a masterpiece of action-adventure gaming that deserves your attention. It is a game that respects your intelligence and creativity, and rewards your curiosity and experimentation. It is a game that tells a compelling story with memorable characters and moral dilemmas, and lets you shape its outcome with your actions. It is a game that will keep you hooked for hours, and make you want to replay it again and again.

Let me preface by saying this: This game is good, but not great. 

In general, it's an improvement over the first game in terms of movement and combat. Traversing through Karnaca felt smooth, more parkour, and more ways to take out someone. 

But ultimately, it's disappointing. I've only ever seen trailers for this game and never the reviews, but personally I felt like the game had a ton of ideas the devs wanted to implement but never got to it. In particular, I disliked how you can't access shops anymore after a certain point, making money worthless. 

The new map itself started out strong. I loved the feel of the new place, but it got bland so, so quickly and it disappointed me that it's no different from Dunwall. Only one place was unique and it was used just ONCE. 

Story and dialogue were meh overall. Nothing was ever really explored, and interactions were too barebones (especially with the main antagonist) and was unsatisfying. Voicework was fine.

In conclusion, I'd recommend this if you enjoyed 1. Gameplay and movement has a lot to offer that you'll love it if you're going the High Chaos route. Just don't expect much for the story and dialogue.

Like the first Dishonored, but more. Bigger story and world, more powers, 2 protagonists, multiple endings. You have the same powers and weapons, and you can still choose how you approach each mission.
If something is in your way you can climb/teleport over it, find a key that unlocks a secret passage, murder everyone and walk through, stealth your way through, or listen to the conversations around you as they always give you a hint on other ways you could bypass it. If you can think of a way past the problems in front of you, chances are it's a real solution.

If you liked Dishonored or love trying loads of different approaches to dangerous situations, this game is for you. The amount of level creativity and player freedom is incredible, and Dishonored 2 is the peak of the "immersive sim" genre.

139782084.review:
Dishonored 2 is one of the few truly great immersive sims. Those are rare enough.

The immersive sim genre is a very shallow pool. Within this pool Arkane Studios is one of the few big fish around and the Dishonored franchise is one of its shiniest scales. There are years of youtube footage documenting the glorious chaos the first game lets an inventive player get away with. That doesn’t even mention the weird and original setting, the peerless environmental storytelling, the unique art style… Am I gushing?

So I am a fan. But I inhabit a very strange corner of the fandom: The ghosting explorer. He is the weird guy who enjoys gliding through the levels leaving as little trace as possible yet can’t resist sticking his nose into every document and voice log lying around and this gets discovered time and again. So, coming from that corner, how does Dishonored 2 measure up to its illustrious ancestor?

After a single playthrough with one of two protagonists, I have to say: Pretty well. As Emily Kaldwell, one of two possible protagonists, I found sneaking towards eventual revenge and redemption great fun.
Dishonored 2 has made quite few changes besides introducing Emily. The art style has made great strides towards photorealism. Especially the environmental art and the textures are an embarrassment of riches. The wood textures on the furniture have to be seen in 4k to be believed.

The level design has lost nothing of its allure. Granted, Serkonos is a very different place with a very different vibe than Dunwall, but the level architecture is just as considered, just as evocative, just as open. And it’s bigger. Generously, wonderfully bigger. Great halls really look grand and lofty. Sunny plazas and grand avenues present daunting challenges to exiled empresses trying to stay invisible. Some of the maps even introduce new mechanics that are never seen again. 

Those are frequently the highlights of the game, but even the less inspired maps are splendid playgrounds full of guards and challenges. It’s a good thing then that Emily has been gifted with a set of supernatural abilities.

The gameplay has evolved quite a bit, even if the core of it stays the same: Blink is still there, if a bit nerfed for Emily, there is a suite of very fun-looking powers to sow chaos and perpetrate bloodshed, choking and slitting throats from behind still works… but so does knocking people out by falling on then, as well as choking them out during a pitched fencing duel and that makes a big difference for all the Emilys out there who do not want to become cold-blooded mass murderers and damning their empire to an age of disease ridden darkness. Back in Corvo’s days, you had to get behind every fool you wanted to grant a good night’s sleep and when one of the guards did spot you, it was either kill or take a quick trip to the loading screen. By giving Emily a non-lethal option for the most dynamic moves of the game, the high karma route of the game is so much more action-packed and enjoyable.

You might have picked up on the fact that the karma system from the first game is still there.

So. The act of playing is more fun than before, and the art direction has been hit with the beauty stick a few hundred times, but what about the story? Dishonored 1 had wonderful world building, but the plot was actually kind of anemic and left some of the more interesting characters quickly by the wayside. I would argue that Dishonored 2 does a better job of telling an actual tale, and it does a better job of making its characters actual characters. There are more interactions with the antagonists, their motivations are much better explored, and the motley crew of supporters around Emily are more fleshed out and charming as well. It still isn’t one of the great stories of video gaming, but it’s an engaging yarn and does a good job of providing additional motivation to see Emily’s crusade for revenge through.

A few criticisms remain: The bone charm crafting system seemed a bit useless, even on the highest difficulty. Some of the secondary objectives seemed a bit obscure. The NPCs had the occasional unexplained freak-out. Little things.
All in all, Dishonored 2 is a successful evolution of Dishonored in every aspect, and can thus be recommended with no reservation whatsoever.

TLDR: All the things Dishonored did, Dishonored 2 does better. If you are a fan of the immersive sim genre, or just curious about it, this game is well worth your time.

139672727.review:
With stellar level design, engaging gameplay, impressive AI, focus on player agency, meaningful progression, and incentive to explore, Dishonored 2 has everything I value in a singleplayer game. There are 2 different sets of powers and an extensive amount of difficulty customization to encourage additional playthroughs as well.

Dishonored 1 + 2 + DotO are kinda like LeBron James. LeBron had outstanding success immediately, but failed to win a title until later in his career. Eventually, he ended up winning 4 championships with 3 different teams. This mirrors the outstanding success of Dishonored 1, as well as the "championship" level design which wasn't fully realized until the sequel. Clockwork Mansion and Crack in the Slab are two of the best video game levels I've ever played, representing the championships that LeBron was able to win in multiple locations. Death of the Outsider and all the replayability represent LeBron's longevity.

Pray that Arkane doesn't fumble the next release

139658420.review:
A very good sequel to a [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/heybabyxxx/recommended/205100]very good game[/url]. This stands out mostly because of the creative level design, like the mission in which you need to travel between two timelines or the one in which the physical layout changes. 

As in its predecessor, you can play this in a pacifist, stealthy way (the most fun, in my book) or cause a bloodbath. You can also be a badass and play without any powers _ I came close to doing that, using only Emily's Far Reach (similar to Corvo's Blink, but less stealthy); and never once I had to use any mana or health elixirs. 

This is way harder to complete without killing anyone than the 1st game and its DLCs, because the world is more reactive. If someone dies indirectly (for example, by being killed by a Clockwork Soldier whose head you destroyed with a crossbow bolt), it will count as a murder by the player. 

Not especially great in terms of story, although not bad, either. It's a little shorter than the original game and there are no DLCs _ instead, a 3rd title was released and it seems it's even shorter. When I play that, I'll link the review here. 

Note that this is not a good game for achievement hunters; I'm a pretty completist player and I've only got 38% of the trophies in my playthrough (against 46% in the 1st game). Way lower than what's usual for me. 

[i]Pro tip:[/i] I strongly recommend that you disable the quest markers, to make exploring the levels much more interesting. There are several other adjustments in the Options menu to tailor the game to your preferences, so don't forget to do it.

139644685.review: nice game but corvo needs more supernatural abilities

139634619.review:
Just a great game. As good if not better than the first one (imo). The story was interesting, the gameplay was great. Some performance issues but not bad enough to cause a negative experience. I loved how in some levels your action impacted the level, just makes the effort you put in feel more rewarding. I did a clean hands, ghost run and I always loved the alternatives. There were plenty of characters I wanted to murder but often the non-lethal way were just more cruel and worth the extra effort. I also played as Emily, as the story is based on her and her powers were very fun. Very different than Corvo and made for interesting game play with multiple ways to approach situations. Also I loved the stealth, I played on normal and I found it the right balance between real stealth and game adapted stealth. The way enemy vision works is really fun and makes the game more immersive. Their eyes are actually their eyes and they don't have any other artificial eyes on their body. 

My less positive points are the civilians and the ending cut scene. As I was playing a ghost run and never wanted to be detected, the civilians could be such a pain in the ass. When civilians spot you it doesn't count as detected but when they see you knock somebody out it does. The problem is that for some reason their vision and detection meter are unforgiving. So often I had to reload saves cause some civilian on some balcony far away saw me do something that a normal game enemy wouldn't see. 

Also I was a bit disappointed in the ending cut scene. I was very excited to see what my game play style and choice of being completely non-lethal would've meant for the world but it showed very very little. Only one choice was shown in a cut scene. All the others were almost pointless. Also there was nothing to indicate I had my entire run on low-chaos. I will try a complete murder run and see if they show more because I was disappointed with this one. (after speedrunning murder run, same feeling at the end of the game). Also something the first game did better was transferring level-based choices to other levels. So if you kill somebody in one level, you might hear or see things about it in the next level which makes the game much more immersive. I missed that here.

Anyway with those points, still a great game, defo worth a buy!

139605984.review: This game was pretty good but i did not enjoy it as much as the original. The original felt unlike any game i had ever played and knew simplicity could make the story feel meaningful. Dishonored 2 relies on many more gimmicks than the original. A full 2 out of the nine levels played completely different than anything else and introduce mechanics specific to those levels. One of the levels I really enjoyed because of a cool time related mechanic. The other was confusing and annoying with a house completely changing layout based on multiple lever pushes. The game uses a lot of ideas that branch out but the problem is if you do not like that, multiple playthroughs (which is encouraged with this series) become kinda less of an idea you really want to explore. The reason for this is because 2 out of a small pool of levels makes up a good chunk of the game and if you do not like said levels you will not want to replay. My other complaint is emily and her powers. corvo is the superior option 100 percent of the time I found myself getting really annoyed when far reach would not go where I wanted to go and i would just start wishing blink was available to me as both characters. For anyone who loved the original as much as i do who wants to buy this please pick corvo, emily is the "canon" option but her gameplay is so much less varied and less fun. You may be wondering at this point why did I even thumb this up? Well that is because i love the gameplay of the series enough even if emily has sub par powers that i still have the time of my life while playing. I think i will revisit this game at least one more time but maybe not as much as the original game which is one of the greatest stealth games ever made in my opinion. This was however an amazing experience that really does add the the grander story of the dishonored universe in many good ways and is a must buy for any fan of the first game.

I got to the level with kirin jindosh's mansion (don't worry, no spoilers) and by the end of it I realized what this game doesn't have that the original perfected. In this level, in this level you are forced to take specific paths towards everything and there are only brief moments where you can stray from this path for the sake of stealth. Compare this to Dishonored 1 where literally every single level was designed such that without even stepping a few feet into a level, you are presented with multiple different paths to take, none of which are forced and are much more up to player interpretation. In Dishonored 1, the levels were structured in such a way that still funneled you to your objective, but if you ever looked around for an alternate way around, you were always rewarded. This level has almost none of that in favor of the next issue:

However, the Kirin's mansion also shows something else. For those unaware, the mansion is effectively a maze, since you have to move sections of the house to actually navigate it at all. This is terrible game design in my opinion. The puzzle presented by a level of dishonored was always how to deal with the enemies, not the level itself. The level is meant to present options, not obstacles.

And then there's the robots / clockwork soldiers. From what I found, there is no easy way to "disable" them in a way that doesn't trigger their detection, so good luck with a full ghost run. UPDATE: What is this trash lmao https://youtu.be/DC0e8YYLj_U
 These guys literally have eyes in the back of their head, so trying to sneak around them is substantially harder than normal people. And this terrible maze level? Filled with these terrible enemies.

I kinda feel like the devs misunderstood what made the first game so good. This mansion level and smaller chunks of previous ones makes me feel like the devs kinda lost the plot with why Dishonored 1 wasn't just a stealth game. It was never one of those games that gives you literally two options; loud or stealthy. It had much more nuance with side quests that unlocked nonlethal options that you could miss if you didn't explore a bit. Dishonored 2 feels a lot more like the devs are just kinda doing the loud or stealthy route. The quest clues are spelled out with zero opportunity for the player to do any sort of thinking. This removes a lot of the fun moments where you as a player feel like you figured something out with realistic clues rather than the game putting up a billboard for you in the form of your player's voice. The nonlethal options are impossible to miss as well, so there's no opportunity to be rewarded in that regard either.

Considering that this mansion level is only like the fourth level of the game, I am sure that there are more opportunities that the devs will fumble later, but this level alone made me write this review.

I also want to add that far reach, Emily's version of blink, is unnecessarily different than blink from Dishonored 1 and it's implementation results in bugs. You can't far reach down something that's too tall, but that was never a limitation for blink. You don't far reach to what your crosshair is placed on, since it is now an arced path for no reason. This game took something that was incredibly straightforward and easy to use and made it noticeably more difficult to use for seemingly no reason.

139311126.review:
Dishonored 2 is a game that truly captivated my imagination. Having played it numerous times, I can confidently say that it is an absolute masterpiece in the realm of stealth-action gameplay. From its richly detailed world to its intricate storyline, every aspect of Dishonored 2 is crafted with meticulous care, making it an unforgettable gaming experience.

The visual design of Dishonored 2 is nothing short of breathtaking. The attention to detail in every environment is remarkable, creating a sense of realism that draws you deeper into the game's world. The combination of stunning art direction, architectural marvels, and atmospheric lighting makes each location a joy to explore. Whether you're sneaking through the cobblestone streets of Karnaca or infiltrating opulent mansions, the world of Dishonored 2 never fails to impress.

The gameplay mechanics of Dishonored 2 are a true testament to its brilliance. The ability to choose between two playable characters, Corvo Attano and Emily Kaldwin, adds a refreshing level of variety to the game. Each character has their unique set of abilities, empowering players to approach challenges in their preferred style. Whether you prefer to rely on stealth, combat, or a mix of both, Dishonored 2 accommodates your playstyle, offering a level of freedom seldom seen in other games.

One of the standout features of Dishonored 2 is its replayability factor. The game's branching narrative and choices influence the outcome of the story, leading to multiple endings. This aspect alone encouraged me to replay the game multiple times, each playthrough offering a fresh and unique experience. The decisions you make have consequences, which adds an extra layer of depth and immersion to the already captivating storyline.

The narrative of Dishonored 2 is intricately woven, filled with political intrigue, personal vendettas, and unexpected twists. The characters you encounter throughout the game are well-developed and leave a lasting impression. From the mysterious Outsider to the enigmatic Delilah, each character has their own motivations and secrets, creating a rich tapestry of storytelling. The voice acting and dialogue further enhance the emotional depth of the game, making it an immersive and unforgettable journey.

Dishonored 2 is a game that continues to enthrall me with each playthrough. Its stunning visuals, engaging gameplay mechanics, replayability, and compelling narrative all contribute to its status as a must-play title. If you enjoy immersive worlds, strategic stealth, and a captivating storyline, Dishonored 2 is an absolute gem that will keep you hooked from start to finish. Prepare to be mesmerized by the intricacies of this exceptional game.

Addendum: (Spoiler alert!)
[spoiler]
In addition to its other outstanding qualities, Dishonored 2 showcases exceptional level design that pushes the boundaries of the genre. Two standout examples of this can be found in the form of the Clockwork Mansion and the time-traveling journey within Stilton's Manor.

The Clockwork Mansion is a marvel of mechanical ingenuity, offering a unique gameplay experience. The mansion itself transforms and reconfigures at the pull of a lever, creating new paths and obstacles in real-time. Navigating this shifting environment requires careful observation and planning, making each encounter a thrilling puzzle to solve. The level of craftsmanship and attention to detail in the design of this location is simply awe-inspiring.

Another noteworthy level is the time-traveling exploration in Stilton's Manor. This section introduces a fascinating twist by allowing players to switch between the past and present within the same physical space. This mechanic not only provides a fresh take on familiar locations but also creates opportunities for creative problem-solving and altering the course of events. The seamless integration of time-travel mechanics into the gameplay showcases the developers' dedication to innovation and adds a layer of complexity that keeps players engaged.

These standout levels, along with the game's overall level design, demonstrate a commitment to pushing boundaries and delivering memorable experiences. Dishonored 2 consistently surprises and challenges players with its inventive and well-crafted environments, making each playthrough a thrilling and immersive journey. [/spoiler]

It's a good game, but I don't know if I'd want a Dishonored 3. Biggest issue I have is that the world and the story are just uninteresting. I had to push myself to finish this game about half way through.

The world is very bleak and quite depressing. Everything is very muted in color. There are definitely cool missions in here, such as the clockwork mansion, but they doesn't offset how uninteresting the world is.

The plot is very linear, you know what the goal is from the very start and it doesn't change by the end. Nothing really does. It didn't feel like there was anything interesting about the villain, it's just: here's a bad person, do these steps to get them, get them, the end. There is no nuance to any of it, no moral choices that I can remember, besides "kill" or "no kill". The ability to takedown bosses non lethally is absolutely appreciated though.

I was doing a perfect stealth walkthrough, so the gameplay was that of a generic first person stealth game with teleports. I collected all the powerups and only ever unlocked active 2 powers, as a lot of the other ones are only useful in a "kill everyone" playthrough.

There is definitely a case for replayability here given 2 playable characters and plethora of mutually exclusive achievements and plenty of skills/boosts for both playstyles.

As for the bugs, there are a few, most notable ones are walking on air issues, sliding off of things and footstep sounds being spammed in certain places like railings and balconies. I think there may have been a few instances of enemies detecting me through walls, most notably the bosses of mission 8 and 9. Overall not that bad.

138731677.review:
Squeak, squeak! As the rats of Dunwall, we have something to say about Dishonored 2, and it's far from delightful. Amidst our scurrying adventures, we can't help but chitter about the flaws of this game. But hey, let's take a break to acknowledge: "We are the rats, the rats, the rats. It's Michael's birthday today, and he has been a good boy this year."

First and foremost, the portrayal of rats in Dishonored 2 is downright insulting! We're not just mischievous pests with no purpose other than to be mercilessly slaughtered. We deserve better treatment than being constantly viewed as disposable obstacles in this grim world. Our natural cunning and adaptability are woefully misrepresented.

Furthermore, the gameplay mechanics often leave us feeling like little more than a nuisance. The protagonists, with their supernatural abilities and arsenal of weapons, can easily dispatch us with little effort. It's disheartening to be relegated to mere cannon fodder, while the game focuses on the human characters and their quests for vengeance or redemption.

The environmental design, while visually impressive, fails to give us rats a true sense of agency. We scurry through the shadows, searching for sustenance and shelter, only to be met with predetermined scripted events. It's as if our presence is nothing more than a superficial backdrop, lacking the depth and interactive elements that could have made our role more meaningful.

And let's not forget the narrative choices made in Dishonored 2. While the game offers multiple paths and outcomes, the treatment of our rat brethren is sorely lacking. We're mere pawns in a power struggle between humans, and our potential to influence the story remains largely untapped. It's a missed opportunity to showcase the intricate relationships and dynamics of the animal kingdom within this dark, dystopian world.

To add insult to injury, the occasional "We are the rats, the rats, the rats. It's Michael's birthday today, and he has been a good boy this year" interjection only serves to confuse and distract from the game's serious tone. It's an odd inclusion that fails to resonate or enhance the experience in any meaningful way.

In conclusion, Dishonored 2 leaves us rats feeling undervalued and overlooked. The lack of depth in our portrayal, the minimal interactivity, and the failure to provide us with a compelling role within the narrative contribute to a disappointing experience. We deserve more than to be trivialized and reduced to inconsequential pests. It's a rat's perspective that's justifiably discontent. Squeak, squeak!

138695943.review:
Fairly good sequel, if you liked the gameplay of Dishonored you'll like this one as well. Emily's skillset is a lot better for stealth + nonlethal gameplay than what the first game had, and two levels (The Clockwork Mansion and Crack in the Slab) have really interesting mechanics that made playing them quite unique.

Unfortunately it has a few issues:
It crashed for me twice in 50 hours of gameplay. (Which isn't a huge issue, autosaves happen often enough but still needs to be pointed out.)
Audio is quite buggy, if you're farther than a few meters from the speaker then the volume drops super low unless you're looking right at them, and you can trigger dialogues from very far away (even through walls), so once the subtitles show up you start to look around to find who is talking (sometimes using the spyglass to zoom onto a nearby wall helps). The game also lowers the volume of the music and other noises when a dialogue is ongoing, but half the time you can't hear the dialogue that triggered this (and it could be caused by some repeated idle mumbling that's not even important). This even happened during a mission-ending cinematic and you can't use the spyglass during cinematics so I stared at subtitles for a while.
Another bug I encountered is that sometimes crawling into crawlspaces (like vents) sometimes takes multiple attempts with different approach angles. This could also happen when vaulting/climbing into a crawlspace.

138354926.review:
A well-executed sequel that delivers more and better content afforded by advances in technology, a custom engine and greater developer experience. The levels are bigger, denser, and designed in ways that simply would not be possible in Unreal Engine 3. The Clockwork Mansion and Stilton Manor are stand-out examples.

Magic powers have more upgrades, runes and bonecharms are more plentiful throughout levels. Bonecharm crafting means unused charms can be scrapped for whalebone for extra runes or custom charms. Emily and Corvo both have unique and well-rounded kits suited for loud or stealthy gameplay; neither are tailored to be played in a specific style.

The game gets more creative and tense with more limitations. There are levels to this game that all deserve a separate playthrough;
[list]
    [*]High chaos
    [*]Low chaos
    [*]High chaos no powers
    [*]Low chaos no powers
    [*]All-zero; Zero deaths ever, zero kills, zero incapacitations besides mission-critical targets, zero detections 
    [*]All-zero no powers
[/list]
Of course, there's two characters so content is effectively doubled for magic runs.

Depth of field re-enables itself when reloading a save, but otherwise the game runs fine without issue. This can be fixed by adding the line "+r_skipDOF 1" as a launch option.

138354576.review: A worthy sequel to it's predecessor.

138349497.review:
Honestly mainly grabbed this game because the developers are the same guys behind Redfall. As everyone might know, that game got poor reception, which made me wonder where it all went wrong. Going back on the developer's timeline I came across this gem... and dear God, it's legendary.

The stealth gameplay paired with the most satisfying assassinations imaginable make for a very addicting gameplay loop. Pair that with superpowers that allow you to traverse the map easier and that keep toying with your enemies, you can play levels over and over and keep learning new approaches to each situation. This is further backed by the level design - sure, there aren't too many levels, but they all have a ton of different routes you can pick aswell. The game also has New Game+ and Mission+, the latter allowing you to play each level with basically all upgrades unlocked. The main campaign is short, without a doubt, but the replayability is incredibly well done.

I cannot recommend this game enough for people who love stealth a ton and may be tired of Ubisoft's approach for that. And again, I genuinely cannot fathom how they went from one of the best games in its genre to a disaster like Redfall. Dishonored made me aware of the greats you can achieve, Arcane, please just strive to get back to that summit. I believe in you.

P.S. I'm totally not an Emily Kaldwin simp

Download game, launch game, game freezes on opening screen at a resolution meant for avatars. Troubleshoot, restart, reinstall, troubleshoot some more, finally the game loads past the initial screen despite not actually changing anything and takes significant tweaking to run mostly stable. Frustrating, but at least I was able to play.

Had to reinstall for outside reasons, now no amount of tweaking, restarting, uninstall/reinstall will get the game to load past the opening art screen. The only way to kill it is through task manager and the problem never changes regardless of the numerous tweaks I've made following others with similar issues.

Way too far past the review window and have a game that can't be played despite having a more than adequate system to run it.

What I've played of the game was solid enough, but buyer beware. Like many titles these days, this is a garbage port, runs poorly even when tweaked, and is host to an unacceptable level of critical issues for what is a seemingly random group of people. Maybe you'll get lucky and be able to run it without issue. I personally prefer not to gamble with my purchases. Guess I should've listened to all  of those speaking about launch and performance issues. That much at least is on me.

137600033.review:
TL:DR: I love dishonored 2 because I love dishonored 1. This game is a 6/10, yet I still recommend you buy it. The sales are great for that. 

Dishonored 2 looks and plays beautifully. Mechanics have been refined and the world feels truly alive. The different powers are very fun to use and, coupled with immaculate level design, allow for a very rewarding and creative epxerience. 

Yet it is almost hollow. The artistic feel of the first game, which brought life to Dunwall, has been replaced by a goofy ah ah photorealism. Items looks great but NPC models really dont fit in. They look out of place with their cartoonish proportions. 

Also...the story. Never have I seen a story attempt to say so much yet say nothing at all. I remember almost every mission from dishonored 1, because they made sense and merged well with the overarching story. In Dishonored 2 I find myself rediscovering each mission whenever I replay it, simply because they are so bland and unmemorable. The lack of "monuments of progression", like the lighthouse or Lady Boyles estate really adds to that issue. 

The missing potential is...sad to watch unfold. 

Also dont try to play this on anything lower than a rx580. A bit of a minus for those who lack graphics card power.
