137414377.review:
What a game. Just finished a low-chaos run. Had fun. Overall I recommend it, especially if you're familiar with the first game, Dishonored.

[SPOILER REVIEW!!!]

I have a lot to say about this, as a game on its own, and as a sequel. I'll be "comparing" it to the first game, as it's a really good way to really put it into perspective.
I think both games are better in their own respective ways. The first game genuinely nails details very well, and I really like the style it has. It's desolate with some wonderfully creepy elements. The weepers had me super creeped out the entire time. I would rather deal with a tallboy than a group of weepers.
Edit: I feel that I should clarify this: I did not grow up with Dishonored. I played it 2-3 weeks ago for the first time, in fact. Nostalgia and awaiting a new game has a HUGE impact on how someone will feel about a sequel. The longer you wait for a sequel, the higher the game will be on a pedestal. ESPECIALLY if you grew up with the game.

This game, the second one, has a different kind of feel, although some moments are still very desolate. I loved the sandstorms, as they felt really eerie to me. The sound queue of a sandstorm coming in, although very loud, was great. I love the sound queues of both games.
Let's get into the improvements.
Combat, the graphics, and general movement just feel good. 
1. Combat felt smoother, especially with the ability to knock out people during a scuffle. I found running away from conflict in the first game felt almost impossible, without using up an entire bar of Mana to do so (or if you quite literally have a very good idea on your surroundings, which not everyone can say about their first few playthroughs).
2. While the puzzles in the early - mid missions were pretty annoying, I could deal with it. It just took patience. I suppose for people looking to fight and have a really exciting experience, this in particular can annoy them, as you were forced to get through all of the grueling searching to get where you needed to go.
This didn't bother me as much because I had dealt with having to be patient in the first game. I had gone through Dishonored, Knife of Dunwall, and Brigmore Witches all without killing anyone and not being detected. It was rough, and required obscene patience. I'm not a big person on combat, as stated in my Dishonored review, but I did genuinely enjoy that aspect of both games anyway.
3. Corvo's redesign is cool, I like it, though I prefer his mask from the first game. Felt more "unhinged", if that makes sense. And I like that he can talk in this one.
4. Story was pretty alright. Not amazing, but not particularly bad, either. I kinda wish there were a tiny bit of clarification, like: how did the Crowned Killer go around causing trouble and killing people, without being seen clearly as a woman with no disguise? I'm sure she had a disguise, but it was never shown. This is an important thing left out, as it was very strictly shown that everyone thought it was Corvo going around killing their enemies. Another kind of inconsistency is: How did Delilah escape the painting that Daud had sealed her in? It is very vaguely referenced by one of her witches iirc, but still not explained. Also, it was nice of Billie Lurk to get an appearance, although the bit where she speaks to Corvo about who she is and what she did was a tad too fan-service. With that said, it's nice to have a tad bit of transparency in a game's story. I'm kind of tired of characters brooding like edgelords and never telling someone they care for about something that would be very important to tell them.
Generally, this game feels really nice with tons of QOL changes since the first game and I can appreciate it, even if first person combat games are not typically my cup of tea.

137358029.review:
Overall its Okay but:

if you're familiar with other Arkane Studio titles, you begin to see the common links or weaknesses in their approach to game design.

big maps, that they just cram a lot of crap props into and create tension with an unnerving sound track.
Dishonored 2 is no different. big beautiful maps, but mostly empty, chock full of worthless props to give the illusion that something or someone [i]was[/i] once there
the enemies are actually fairly minimal in numbers, but daunting by being able to detect you from 300 feet away (mitigated with perks), making them seemingly difficult to get past.
 but after you learn all the tricks the game has to offer, they are too easy... almost boring... as they all behave the same way: scan the area, then walk in a looping path, and chase you down directly even if you hide (just climb upwards to evade).

the story was okay, artwork is really good, mechanics are good... movement is weird at times, in some areas of the map (especially empty areas) it seems like you are a camera on a unicycle... which oddly was the same feeling i got in another Arkane game: Prey.

some parts of the game  have amazing flow and seem really well put together like a top tier AAA first person game should have, but other parts of the game are just a boring slog which pulls the overall rating down.

would only recommend only on sale, otherwise skip.

it's a decent game, but not "overwhelmingly steam positive derrrr" good.
it certainly doesn't have the charm or wow factor of the first Dishonored.

also this game has persistent Vignette, which you cannot turn off... but I found a mod over on nexus that cleans it up... 
if you tab over to the "posts" section under the "remove vignette" mod, you will see someone that wrote their own version (and links to) which also gets rid of the motion blur when sprinting... highly recommended to get that one (its just an ini file.)
if you too get annoyed with a big fuzzy black edged border on your monitor, every time you crouch, you're going to want to get it.

137098427.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

136959835.review:
Dishonored 2 is a brilliant sequel that improves on almost every aspect of the original game. It is a thrilling adventure that lets you reprise your role as a supernatural assassin in a fascinating world where magic and technology clash. You can choose to play as either Emily Kaldwin or Corvo Attano, each with their own perspective and set of powers, and decide the fate of the Empire as you face a new threat from a mysterious usurper12. The game offers you a remarkable level of freedom and choice, allowing you to customize your abilities, weapons and gadgets, and approach each mission in multiple ways.

One of the most impressive features of Dishonored 2 is the level design, which is varied, intricate and full of surprises. Each mission takes you to a different location, from the sunny streets of Karnaca to the eerie Clockwork Mansion, and challenges you to adapt to the environment and the enemies. The levels are also filled with secrets, collectibles and optional objectives that reward exploration and experimentation. The game also introduces new gameplay mechanics, such as the time-traveling device in the Crack in the Slab mission, which adds another layer of complexity and fun to the gameplay1.

The graphics of Dishonored 2 are stunning, thanks to the new Void Engine that enhances the lighting, shadows and textures. The game has a distinctive art style that blends realism and stylization, creating a rich and immersive atmosphere. The game also boasts a superb voice cast that includes Rosario Dawson, Vincent D’Onofrio, Sam Rockwell, Pedro Pascal and Robin Lord Taylor1, who deliver excellent performances that bring the characters to life.

Dishonored 2 is a game that I can’t get enough of, as it offers so much replay value and challenge. The game adapts to how you play, changing the world and the story based on your actions and decisions1. You can choose to be stealthy or lethal, merciful or ruthless, and see how your choices affect the outcome. The game also has multiple difficulty modes, including a custom mode that lets you tweak various parameters to suit your preference. The game also features a New Game Plus mode that lets you carry over your powers and upgrades from a previous playthrough2.

If you are looking for a game that combines action, stealth, magic, story and choice in an amazing world, look no further than Dishonored 2. It is one of the best games I have ever played, and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves immersive and engaging games.

136788756.review:
[h1] Positives [/h1]
[list]
    [*]Massive amount of player choice in gameplay approach
    [*]Unique art direction
    [*]Creative level design
    [*]Strong replayability
[/list]

[h1] Neutral [/h1]
[list]
    [*]The story isn't as investing as it could be
    [*]Choosing between two protagonists has little effect on gameplay
    [*]There's almost [i]too[/i] much choice
[/list]

[h1] Negatives [/h1]
[list]
    [*]Several characters are paper-thin in substance
    [*]Combat is lacking
    [*]The No-Powers run is especially restrictive
    [*]Achievement hunters will dislike being forced to replay the game
[/list]

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
[i]Dishonored 2[/i] offers players a great amount of freedom in their choice on how to approach its intricately crafted levels. Stealth lovers will rejoice and action-adventure fans will have something to enjoy here too. Arkane has done an exceptional job with making the world of [i]Dishonored[/i] feel especially lived in to the point where exploration almost becomes second nature.

Where the game struggles is with its characterisation of its cast and the story in general. Even having played the first game in the series, you'll find little to no emotional heaviness in [i]Dishonored 2[/i]'s story, worsened further by the decision to keep you in first-person for the entirety of its length, constantly in the action, and moving through its cast with incredible brevity. Those seeking to be in the action as soon as possible will find no issue with this, but those seeking memorable characters and an unforgettable plot will be disappointed.

The next egregious fault with the game will have to be how player choices affect the story. A reactive world is feigned; the story that constantly shifts to accommodate whether you spare or kill your standard enemy, civilians, and your primary targets, but in reality, these changes are barely noticeable outside of unique dialogue, and the story's already-lacking presence are only changed through simple scene swaps. It makes one wander whether or not this element of the game should've been scrapped in favour of telling an engaging story with satisfying character arcs, twists, and themes. There's nothing truly emotionally meaningful to be gained from the story for these changes to have any lasting impact on players.

Where the story falls, the gameplay picks up the pieces. There's almost too much freedom provided to players, with interesting systems, abilities, and routes available to them (depending on which playstyle they decide to pursue). It's woefully easy to find yourself reliant on an approach that doesn't bother encouraging you to explore the game's system's further, though that may be more dependent on players' creativity. It's a very individual issue but one that may only be noted by those seeking to get the most out of the game.

[i]Dishonored 2[/i] isn't a game you buy for its story—you buy it for its gameplay. It's undeniably well-crafted, with immense thought put into its designs across many departments. Even if the writing will leave you wanting, anyone remotely interested in this franchise and the open-ended gameplay Arkane provides will find some value here.

[b]Should you buy it?[/b]: When it's on sale.

[h1] 3/5 [/h1]

Awesome game, basically took what they did in Dishonored 1 and made it way better. A ton of different options on how to do things, with the limit being the creativity of the player on how they want to go through the levels. Every time you go off somewhere to explore you always end up coming across something, ammo, money, sidequests, and interactable objects that can make things easier or even let you bypass huge parts of the mission. Tldr; This game is like Assassins Creed + Hitman, with superpowers, definitely recommend.

136537199.review:
I had Dishonored 2 on my wish list since it's release and after years, when it was on a sale for 10 bucks or so, I finally got it and I'm glad I did. If you liked the first one, definitely play the sequel. It improves on it's predecessor in every way I could imagine. 
The movement is fluent. The combat is really fun and once you start tinkering around, surprisingly deep with a lot of little tricks to try. The levels are beautifully crafted with a lot of attention to detail and you can really feel how much thought went into making them play out. This makes getting around the maps very fun and non-lethal runs feel really rewarding IMO. Also there are a lot of new mechanics being introduced while the game unfolds which add a lot to the already fantastic gameplay.
There are only two negatives that stood out to me. The first one was the overall story and the villain: They are perfectly serviceable as an overall context but nothing extraordinary, which - honestly - they don't really need to be.
I did not care for the final level and the ending though. I expected something grand after all the crazy stuff before but the final level was definitely a let-down. I can imagine that development time ran out in the end but that's just my guess.
Still, I absolutely love this game and am looking forward to playing it again, thank you Arkane!

136499966.review:
Amazing game. Dishonored 2 builds what the previous game created and gives you even more optons to be sneaky or to go stabby stabby on your enemies. 
.
[h1]Story[/h1]
.
You can still play as Corvo Attano, but the main character is his daughter Emily who becomes the new Empress of the Empire described in the previous game. A mysterious new face Delilah appears suddenly and takes the empire from you, using powerful magic to turn Corvo into stone.
Then again the enigmatic Outsider offers you his occult powers in order to help you take back your empire and strike Delilah down
.
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
.
As Emily, you have a few different and unique powers that Corvo didnt had. My favorite is Shadow Walk which turns you into a living shadow wthat can crawl on the ground undetected or quickly assassinate enemies. Reminds me os the Lasombra clan of Vampire: the Masquerade.
The game has some quite unique and memorable missions like the Clockwork Mansion and A Crack in the Slab which are some of the most creative ideas ive seen in a video game. You need to play them to understand. Its really remarkeable.
.
[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
.
Overal this game is a must play for fans of the stealth genre or people who enjoy games with a careful and believable world building. And yes, you need to play Dishonored 1 in order to understand and enjoy Dishonored 2, as its clearly a sequel.

136362265.review:
For some reason Dishonored 2 never became a hit like it's predecessor. It came and went and wasn't talked about all that much. And I didn't play it until now, wrongly assuming it wasn't nearly as good as the first Dishonored. And even though I still somewhat prefer the original, objectively speaking Dishonored 2 took everything that made Dishonored great and improved it to near perfection. It is a phenomenal game that does what every sequel should.
Dishonored 2 takes the already high replayability of Dishonored 1 and basically doubles it. You can now choose to play as two different characters with very different power sets. They both feel great to play as and neither one feels tacked on; dialogue and storytelling change slightly depending on which character you are playing as. It also (and this is the best improvement) adds quite a few options for non-lethal playthroughs. You can now engage in melee combat and take out enemies without killing them, something that wasn't really an option in the first game. 
Another great addition is new game+ which not only finally allows you to replay Dishonored with a fully powered character but also lets you mix powers from both characters which raises both replayability and fun factor even further.
Visuals are also improved and the game looks fantastic without losing Arcane's signature artstyle. Levels are bigger with more secrets to discover and they are a joy to traverse. Like in Dishonored 1, there are multiple paths you can use to get through each level and, combined with different ways you can play, basically guarantees that no 2 playthroughs feel the same. Not only are levels bigger and prettier but they are (2 especially come to mind) probably the best examples of a genius level design. Some of these levels will not only leave you awestruck but genuinely wondering: "How the hell did they do that?"
Enemy AI is also improved...barely. Enemies are for the most part still quite dumb and oblivious but they do seem to spot you faster although, I must admit, I didn't really enjoy their "improved" intelligence. For example, in Dishonored 1 leaning was overpowered. Your head could be sticking around the wall staring enemy straight in the face and he would be oblivious to your presence. It was stupid, but it was funny and endearing, one of those little quirks that make a game special. Leaning is nerfed in Dishonored 2 and I miss it.
Storywise, Dishonored 2 is even less special than the first game. Despite both games having a roster of celebrity actors, writing and dialogue in both games feel weird and unnatural. It's not bad, just unremarkable.
Definitely the weakest aspect of both games, although I do think it's worse in this one. 
Another thing Dishonored 2 does a little worse is it's downtime. Between missions you'll be chiling on a ship with some npcs and I must say this is a pretty lame hub area. There isn't much to see and do here and not many characters to interact with. Contrast this with the hub area in Dishonored 1 where you had more npcs and a part of the city to yourself and it's pretty dissapointing. 
But these are all nitpicks that don't really detract from the game's accomplishments. Dishonored is all about gameplay and exploration and both are done beyond excellent. It's a shame (and simply incomprehensible) that this game, as well as Prey, didn't do better commercially. Nobody does player choice better than Arcane and they should have all the success in the world.

136207026.review:
Dishonored 2 is a sequel to the acclaimed stealth action game Dishonored, which was released in 2012. In this game, you can choose to play as either Corvo Attano, the protagonist of the first game, or Emily Kaldwin, his daughter and the empress of the Empire of the Isles. The game takes place 15 years after the events of the first game, when a mysterious woman named Delilah Copperspoon claims to be Emily’s aunt and usurps her throne with the help of a group of conspirators. You have to escape from your palace and travel to the coastal city of Karnaca, where you have to find allies and uncover the truth behind Delilah’s plot.

The game is a stealth action game, which means that you have to use your skills and abilities to infiltrate various locations and complete your objectives. The game gives you a lot of freedom and choice in how you play, you can decide whether to be stealthy or aggressive, lethal or non-lethal, merciful or ruthless. Your actions have consequences, not only for the story and the characters, but also for the world and the gameplay. The game has a chaos system, which measures how much violence and disorder you cause in each mission. The higher your chaos level, the more hostile and dark the world becomes.

The game’s main feature is its stealth gameplay, which is very well-designed and satisfying. You have access to various tools and gadgets, such as a crossbow, a pistol, grenades, mines and more. You also have access to supernatural abilities, such as blink, which lets you teleport short distances, dark vision, which lets you see through walls and detect enemies, domino, which lets you link the fates of multiple enemies, and more. You can upgrade your abilities and equipment by finding runes and bone charms throughout the game. You can also customize your difficulty level by adjusting various parameters, such as enemy awareness, detection speed, health regeneration and more.

The game’s stealth gameplay is very rewarding and fun, because it lets you be creative and clever with your approach. You can use your abilities and tools to sneak past guards, distract them, knock them out or kill them silently. You can also explore the environment and find alternative paths, hidden secrets and optional objectives. The game has a lot of replay value, because you can try different playstyles, choices and outcomes. The game also has a new game plus mode, which lets you start a new game with all your abilities and equipment from a previous playthrough.

The game’s graphics are also amazing, the city of Karnaca is very detailed and immersive. The game has a distinctive art style that blends realism and stylization. The game has different districts and themes that reflect the culture and history of Karnaca. The game also has dynamic weather and lighting effects that create different atmospheres and moods. The game’s sound design is also excellent, the voice acting is superb and the music is fitting and memorable.

The game’s story is also compelling and well-written. The game has interesting characters that have their own personalities and motivations. The game has multiple endings that depend on your actions and choices throughout the game. The game also has some twistsand surprises that keep you engaged and curious. The game also has some DLCs that add more content and story to the game.

The game’s main flaw is its system requirements, which are very high and demanding. The game runs poorly, even on a high-end PC with a powerful graphics card like a 3080. You may encounter frame drops, stuttering, glitches and crashes. The game also has some bugs and issues that can affect your gameplay and progress. The game is not very well optimized and may require some tweaking and patching to run smoothly.

Dishonored 2 is a stealth action game that offers a lot of freedom and choice in how you play. It has a thrilling and immersive gameplay, a stunning graphics and a captivating story. The game is not for everyone, it can be challenging and frustrating at times. It also requires a very good PC to run properly. But if you are looking for a unique and satisfying stealth action game, Dishonored 2 might be the right choice for you.

136202598.review:
Dishonered 2 is a great follow up to the first installment. In some ways a huge improvement and in other it fails to capture the same dark and gritty world tone that the first game really nailed down.
This is stealth action taken to great heights and if you like that genre this is a must-play. 
The two protaganists feature similar but yet vastly different playstyles and it is clear which the game developers orignially prefered you should play (emily). That doesn't ruin any of the experience for those who come back to play our hero Corvo Attano again tho.
There is plenty of ways to tackle each mission and ways to replay the game for an even harder or different experience. 
The game is short. But to me it seems like it was made this way to not feel padded out with grindy missions and sidequests. Still. I feel like I need more after having played it all the way through.
I cannot recommend this game enough, especially after having played the masterpiece that is Dishonered 1.

136198380.review:
Dishonored 2 is a thrilling and immersive game that I thoroughly enjoyed playing. The flexibility it offers allows for a unique and engaging experience, with multiple playstyles and abilities available for players to choose from. The world-building is superb, with richly detailed environments that are a joy to explore.

However, the game does have a few issues. Firstly, the optimization is not great, and it can run poorly on older hardware. Additionally, some of the abilities can feel unpolished, which can lead to frustration when trying to use them effectively.

Another aspect of the game that may not appeal to everyone is the emphasis on "magic" in the story. While I understand that it is integral, I still feel that the first game with more "realistic" levels were more fun to explore than the gimmicky levels we got here, partly because they felt lived in and they fit the assassin playstyle better.

Overall, I would give it an 8 out of 10.

136190994.review:
Compared to the first game, Dishonored 2 has way more variety in terms of powers and weapons. The levels feel about the same size but there is a lot more packed into small places than the first. This game succeeds the first in every way except story. The story is not bad by any stretch of the word, but it's kind of a repeat of what happened last time in terms of what you are fighting for and getting back a family member. While that may drag the intensity of the stakes down, the characters and dialogue really save the story to be much more engaging. 

You can pick between playing Corvo and Emily, it's very clear that the devs want you to be Emily but the way I see it why wouldn't I pick the guy that I played last time and feel more invested in. Not to say that Emily isn't a intriguing character but I feel more attachment to Corvo. Which leads me to my second negative opinion about this game. I do not like the fact that picking between one character or another leads to pretty much the same dialogue between all the characters. Playing through the game the second time makes you not really care how the dialogue differs, because it kinds doesn't other than the other characters saying your name and the in between mission cutscenes that last like 2 minutes, which those in between are really good but it makes it all the more frustrating when that kind of diversity between the characters isn't shared elsewhere in the story.

Now take what I said about the story between both characters and throw that out the window when it comes to gameplay. Holy crap is the diversity in abilities between them make multiple breakthroughs so much fun. While in Dishonored 1 you basically had to ask yourself "will you be lethal or non lethal this run",  Dishonored 2 asks you like 5 different questions on how you want to play this run besides just being lethal and non lethal. For doing that and still not holding your hand like a child I truly respect the people at Arkane Studios.

Overall, if you loved the first one you'll most certainly love this one. A great sequel to a great game.

Level design is immaculate; plays with verticality, solid environmental storytelling, lots of secrets and goodies buried here or there, mwah, chef's kiss. Void abilities are a blast to use, and make both stealth and combat-focused playstyles feel exciting. Missions can play out as bloodbaths or you can ghost your way through, and if you ignore collectibles (save that for New Game+ or ++), you can be in and out in a minute or two once you know level layouts.

Dishonored 2 is absolutely my new favorite game of all time.
I'm so stunned it took me so long to play this considering I loved Dishonored so much years ago.

The amount of time they spent giving you options, places to explore, things to see, different ways of playing- ugh, it's a freaking masterpiece.

Either way, this game feels almost limitless at times and it's so exciting having so many things to do and so many different options at your disposal. For what you pay, you get a landslide of contet that keeps you engaged for hours and hours to come.
The visuals, the music, always ridiculously good. I've seen some comments saying the game was running rather sluggish for them, but I have a pretty subpar PC and I never even had a hiccup once so I'm sure it'll be different for everyone.

I really don't have the words to describe how much I love this game, and my heart breaks knowing it's most likely over after DOTO. I would give up many other games to see the Dishonored series come back to life.
Literally nothing bad to say about this game, not one.
1000/10

135212086.review:
Dishonored 2 is what I imagine assassins creed would be in first person. The cities feels huge with lots of exploring and buildings to enter, lots of npcs and enemies roam through the city making it feel quite alive.

There’s many ways you can progress a mission and it’s completely up to the player how they want to proceed. You can stealth or go on a killing spree, or simply do a little of both. There’s really no wrong way to do any of the missions in the game. Attacking enemies will often call out for help and before you know it you are surrounded, or you can ninja your way through the game and try to go completely unnoticed.

The story lets you play as either Corvo or Emily, where you will begin your journey to take back your rein and claim the throne.
The story is about 10-12hrs long and much longer if you go the pacifist route and try to stealth the entire game.

There’s tons and tons of collectibles and things to find, you will never run out of things to look for. There’s also runes that are used to give the player an unlockable skill tree where you can gain powers to help you through the story. There’s also charms you can equip that will give you advantages such as having more powerful weapons, faster charging mana, or even charms that will increase your power but give you negative side effects, such as taking more damage.

The graphics are decent, some of the models look a bit ugly but I think this is more the art style than anything else. The voice acting was done really well, with everyone sounding their part. The music was also good and added the right amount of tension to the game.

I played on steam deck at 1152x720 and the game ran at an almost constant 60fps and looked great. I didn’t really have to sacrifice the settings to get it to run well.

Overall an outstanding game

8.5

Probably one of my favorite games of all time.

135065556.review:
A huge improvement over Dishonored 2 in almost every respect. The stealth mechanics, skills, items, levels, story, graphics are all even better than in its predecessor. The general story of the original was a bit more exciting in its premise and felt more novel but we can't expect a sequel to top, since it needs to fit into the framework given by the world building and story of the first installment of the franchise.

I was particularly excited about the time swap mechanic introduced in a later level. I had not seen this in any other game before and found it not only surprising but very interesting. I would not need this to exist in the entire game, it would get tiresome, but it was truly surprising that suddenly the rules of the game are changed after many hours of gameplay and you are confronted with having to approach things differently and learn something new, this was the best part of the game for me.

135060375.review: Even though story-wise, the gut-wrenchingly captivating story of the first part of the game is unbeatable in its effect, with the second part, Arkane Studios did their best to match the genius of it. And when it comes to my personal opinion I have to say they definitely more than met the expectations a player could have after playing the initial part. Core game mechanics are not touched and are merely reworked. Perfectly fitting new game mechanics are introduced. Additionally the art style changes in an interesting manner. While Dishonored 1 portrays a sinister steampunk-esque scenery in London, Dishonored 2 portrays a light-mooded victiorian-style era world, concluding the game in a coherent way. Overall one has to admit that Arkane did not fail to deliver on this one. 10/10

134725257.review:
Dishonored was one of those lightning in the bottle games where it felt revolutionary because it felt completely fresh in several ways, delivering an intriguing and uniquely rendred world, with painterly flair given to environments and characters. Dishonored 2 doesn't take any major steps like that forward - and yet it is a great game and a great sequel.

For those unaware, Dishonored is this first person stealth and combat game with open levels, magic powers, and staple for videogames moral choices of "do you kill or just knock a guy out". Which doesn't sound that exciting when spoken, but thing is, they really nail it, the levels are fun explore because there's resources to collect but also narrative bits of storytelling and environmental design to explore, there's always a few passages and options to pick from, and any problem has several solutions, including stuff developers didn't foresee, stuff like physics and combining powers can get pretty crazy fun to mess with.

Another bit is the world, well thought out, and devs took great effort to make it convincing and show it off in many ways. The world is truly intriguing, Victorian era, steampunk but not really, with occult cosmic horror supernatural but offering some real sense mystery to it. In the sequel here, instead of grim not-London Dunwall you go to sunny but as gloomy and violent Greece-inspired Karnaca. The place that went trough a golden age under previous ruler but under current duke people are getting poor and desperate as he squanders wealth. One really nice bit is how writers, artists and level designers really upped their ante with visual part, the city is real cool even if the average living areas like apartments are somewhat samey, but the core locales are all amazing, like inventor's mansion with sliding walls and platforms, arts conservatory squatted by supernatural, a royal palace that feels both fit for a 19th century monarch yet simultaneously immensely modernist. General narrative, while delivering some twists, sticks to same formula as original game, very closely so.

Gameplay-wise you get two characters now, with Emily Kaldwin the new character getting new powers, even if some are remixes of Korvo's, they're still offering fun takes, whereas Korvo sticks to old game's ones though with some additions. The equipment is mostly same as original, the flintlock, blade, crossbow with different bolts and some explosives, it's all still there, with additions. Nothing that would make a jaw drop but not fixing what's not broken either. Also the new game plus allows you to mix both characters unique powers, which can open up brand new possibilities.

Art-wise, the environments are definitely the highlight, but everything else is also of finest Arkane quality. The stylization level is bit subtler than in original though, less warped and varied character proportions, less brushstrokes visible on brick textures. Would be sad if newer art direction wasn't as gorgeous.

I recommend this, it's great and memorable. It's not too long of a game, just don't try to be mr perfect stealth pacifist on your very first run and have some fun messing with violent options too.

Very overrated.

134660431.review:
95/100

Easily one of the most well-made games I've ever played. Apparently it ran terribly on release, but that isn't surprising... Bethesda published the game.

I can't speak for 2016 but in 2023 it feels like Arkane really took their time balancing the player's powers and map/level design, so the game looks and plays beautifully. However, I probably feel this way because I play on Iron Mode (one life, no reloading your save if you die), so having strong powers feels like a fair trade-off. 

Aside from the wonderful gameplay, the world itself looks great and feels very alive. NPCs across each map are having little conversations with one another, sharing information you may need to know and giving flavor to the world. There are various collectibles to find, all of which feel good to stumble upon but aren't crucial to find. There's always more than one way to reach your destination. There's even a healthy amount of true replayability in the game: there are various "this or that" choices over the course of the game which can steadily change how the story develops as well as measurements of how stealthy or aggressive you play which has an immediate and obvious impact on the world. 

Highly recommend you buy this, even at full price, because it's easily worth the $30 price tag. That said, if you're on the fence just do the usual: check the steamDB price chart history. A game will usually go on sale around the same times every year.

134323070.review:
Honestly, I wanted to love this game. I really did. I really enjoyed Dishonored 1, but this game has the issues sequels do. It falls flat, but not how you'd expect.

Pros: Game has some interesting powers, the possession and shadow-sneak are great. The level designs are lovely, easily the best part of the game. Combat is fine, it feels fluid and dynamic. 


Cons I'm 80% sure any game tester was drunk as fuck. There are many faults, the physics are wonky, and result in npcs dying from arbitrary things such as them falling onto a flaming bottle. Being spotted from across the map while in a bush, while simultaneously being able to walk right next to another npc while in light and not be spotted. Trying to stealth while collecting things is equivalent to injecting stables into your fingernails. Guards are both hyper alert and dumb because the AI is terrible. The characters are...mediocre at best. Powers sometimes just...will not work the way they should, especially the teleport, good luck ever using teleport to go down. If you were to compare this to a game that I find has good stealth, Metro Exodus, it falls flat a lot. Bonecharms feel heavily combat focused, and if you are trying to stealth/non-lethal 80% of them are entirely useless. It's like the game wants to promote being non-leathal to be a good person while going heavily out of the way to punish you as a player and character. It's easily the most frustrated I've been at a game in a very long time. Finally, the biggest issue; graphics. it's not that it doesn't look good, because it actually looks great, but you will struggle to actually look at it because you'll want to throw up, between the odd refresh rate, the mouse movements, FOV water effects and head bobbing it's like trying to ride a tilt-a-while and play an FPS at the same time, I've never had a game make me this nauseous, and i'm not the only one. I really do not understand how a game tester could have missed how dizzying the game makes you feel from only an hour or two of moving around.

Compared to Dishonored 1 I find this game immensely less fun and quite frustrating overall, and I basically feel sick anytime I play it due to many glaring issues of the graphical decisions made by the dev team. I still plan to beat the game before I rate it on story, but even that feels much more flat than Dh1. I'm around the last few chapters as I write my review, but I highly doubt there'll be a twist big enough to make me take back the negative for the story.

Overall, I'd give the game a solid 3 or 4/10. The biggest deduction coming from the nausea, some from a flat feeling story and a little bit on the AI, but I never expected much from a team run by Bethesda. The only positives are that the levels are great themselves, environments are interesting, powers are quite cool and combat(if you go that route) is fun. It feels like a lot of things were hastily done, such as the bonecharms. If you want to enjoy stealth, there's far better games, and if you want interesting physic based assassination Hitman easily is better.

133340003.review:
Recently got all achievements on this fantastic sequel to the Dishonored franchise.

What I really like about this sequel is that it did everything, that the prequel did, but [i] better [/i].
Mechanically you get more powers to play with, as well as a new character to play and experience the game with, which also ups the games replay value. Although I encountered some bugs and glitches while playing, they didn't impact my experience heavily. The leveldesign is one of the strongest aspects of the franchise and D2 did not dissapoint. Many different ways to get to a goal. [spoiler] My favorite mission is probably The "Clockwork Mansion" or  "A Crack in the Slab", as both really are the best examples of phenomenal leveldesign. That and fricking time travel, duh. [/spoiler]
The plot is pretty straight forward. There wasn't really a major twist, at least none that Dishonored fans didn't see a mile away... The interesting new and old characters got fleshed out and given some more background and personality, which I really appreciate. That doesn't make up for the lack of a twist or interesting narrative though. The only compelling narrative is the chaos system, but I think the impact of this system fails to make it feel like your playstyle impacts anything that happens around you. They do impact some things, but I do feel like it could have been more polarizing.
The worldbuilding is as stellar as in the first game. Really liked the change of pace from the dingy, dark alleys of Dunwall City to the bright and lively streets of Karnaca. In addition to that the graphics are stunning and still hold up in 2023. I really like the artstyle and feel that in D2 Akane really perfected it. The attention to detail is also a really nice touch and really shows how much love they put into the game.
The music is, as in the first game, excellent. It really sells the dark steampunk setting while still having this elegance to it, hinting at the royal aspect that stretches through the story [spoiler] (Emily getting her throne back/Corvo, Royal Protector, ending a coup to restore order). [/spoiler] I love the sounddesign, it really adds to immersion.
I enjoyed collecting the achievements. They were challenging without being grindy or luckbased and really gave me the opportunity to experience the game through very different approaches and playstyles, as well as using mechanics that are usually rarely utilized in an immersive playthrough.

In summary; A great sequel to a great franchise. Plotwise not the greatest, but the game makes up for it in fun mechanics, leveldesign and love to detail in a compelling world.

Mechanics: 10/10
Plot/characters: 6/10
Worldbuilding: 10/10
Sound/Music: 10/10
Graphics/aesthetics: 10/10
Achievements: 10/10

[b] Total: 9.3/10 [/b]

And once again you can run through this game and literally dismember all of your enemies or you can play start to finish without killing a single person.

133254060.review: Dishonored 2 is the peak of the stealth genre. I would argue that D2 is an upgrade over the original in almost every way. The graphics are incredible and unique. The combat is visceral, brutal, and incredibly rewarding. With new powers, and tools, the possibilities for approaching levels are endless. The story is compelling, the characters are memorable, and the ability to play as Corvo or Emily, high or low chaos, makes it well worth replaying multiple times. There's a NG+ mode to facilitate this as well, so you can enjoy a completely OP all powers run (or you can customize the difficulty to make it as brutal and unforgiving as possible). If you enjoyed D1, or you're interested in this game/genre, I can't recommend it enough. This game is incredibly underrated, and has some of the best level design, period. Give it a shot, you won't regret it!

133039398.review:
Dishonored 2 is my favourite video game of all time. I absolutely recommend it to anybody who has an appreciation for level design, artistic direction and atmosphere in video games. Arkane Studios is, in my opinion, leading the field in these categories and I have never played a game with such intricate attention to detail and no game apart from this has shown complete mastery of the ability to tie level design and level interaction with world building, atmosphere and ambience. 

From the first mission, regardless of if you have played the first Dishonored, (which I very much recommend as well) the world shows you its history, its culture, its traditions, its politics, and how its people live almost purely through level design. This is a recurring theme in the game; Arkane Studios shows a mastery of world building without shoving dialogue in your face which in most games is distracting and tedious. The world of Dishonored however, perfectly accommodates for the natural gameplay progression you take as you move through the world. The game rewards you for exploring, it rewards you for showing a curiosity in the world, while also inspiring and nurturing that curiosity as you play. There is almost never a wrong way to do things, and doing things your own way is also rewarded, you rarely feel as if you have been forced to do something in a way you don't want to, and the game lays out a myriad of options for you to progress with. Around my 15th playthrough of the game, i had still discovered new secrets, new answers, and sometimes new questions of the world that the game builds around you. The immersion is unmatched in the industry and the gameplay mechanics never feel like they're fighting the immersion, rather gently encouraging it. Something I love about the approach taken in the game is the choice it gives you to read more about the world. Scattered around your environment are notes, posters, book extracts, even conversations between people that are totally optional to interact with or observe, but if you choose to really embrace the search for knowledge about the world around you, offer such a rewarding and interesting pool of world building and development that can encourage more and more playthroughs of the game. The world around you changes, sometimes subtly and sometimes massively depending on your choices, and you can play the game so many times and experience a noticeably different world each time. This is not just in reference to the chaos system, but there are also different choices separate from that which also make impacts on the world and even small things like wanted posters change depending on if you've been spotted at all, for example.

To touch on the gameplay a little, I truly believe Dishonored as a whole are the only games to have mastered the first person stealth genre. The difficulty is customisable, with difficulty options feeling organic and natural, while increasing the difficulty for those wanting a challenge, but also easier options for those wanting to take the time to sink themselves into the world and atmosphere without worrying about enemies. The powers feel intuitive to use and all of them are worth exploring, with the rune system creating another reason to explore to try new powers. Even disregarding the powers, the swordplay and sneaking mechanics feel great and natural and the movement is smooth and feels like it follows the player's inputs very well. There are a myriad of both lethal and non lethal options to take down enemies which encourages you to play the game how you want to and also allows you to set fun challenges like Ghost/Clean Hands runs. I play hard-stealth 99% of the time so I can't speak much on the combat but from what I have tried and seen it is very enjoyable and offers a lot of creativity and lets you think on your feet as you fight.

Overall, Dishonored is an experience you will not get from any other game and has so much replay value for so many reasons that I definitely recommend it to anyone considering it.

132884337.review:
Dishonored 2 is an exceptional game that builds upon the success of its predecessor. As a fan of the stealth genre, I found the game to be both thrilling and challenging. The game is set in a beautifully crafted world that is filled with detail, from the sprawling city of Karnaca to the hidden secrets lurking in every corner. The level design is remarkable and varied, allowing for a range of gameplay styles and approaches.

One of the strengths of Dishonored 2 is the choice it gives to players in terms of gameplay style. As with the first game, players can choose to play as either a ruthless assassin or a more stealthy and non-lethal approach. This flexibility ensures that the game is suitable for both aggressive players who want to engage in combat, as well as more strategic and patient players who prefer to remain unseen.

In terms of comparisons, Dishonored 2 shares similarities with the classic stealth game Thief 2. Both games offer intricate levels and an immersive world to explore, and both rely on stealth as the primary gameplay mechanic. However, Dishonored 2 brings a fresh and unique twist to the genre, incorporating magic abilities and a more fluid movement system that sets it apart from other games in the genre.

While Dishonored 2 is an excellent game, it falls slightly short of its predecessor, Dishonored 1. The first game had a more cohesive and focused narrative, and the plot twists were more impactful. However, Dishonored 2 compensates for this with its improved gameplay mechanics and level design.

Overall, Dishonored 2 is an excellent game that offers players a thrilling and challenging stealth experience. While it may not be quite as good as the first game in terms of narrative, it more than makes up for it with its incredible gameplay, world-building, and replayability. If you're a fan of the stealth genre or looking for a unique and engaging game to play, Dishonored 2 is definitely worth checking out.

I played through it on very hard difficulty with no powers on my first play through, and while I feel I limited myself a bit, it also opened up the way I approached each level. I had to be more stealthy and creative with how I moved around. I can definitely see myself in the future replaying Dishonored 1 & 2 but playing the game in a completely different way making the experience almost brand new. In all honesty, I mainly enjoyed the gameplay and I wasn't really too intrigued with the story too much. I think it was interesting, but I feel like the player didn't get to see Delilah enough for the immortality ritual and ending fight to feel exciting. Also, at the beginning it felt a little silly seeing Corvo, this beast of an assassin/protector, being easily turned to stone within seconds (i played as Emily). Felt weird considering how easy the final boss fight was. Still though, the story was not bad and lead to some interesting gameplay mechanics such as the device given to you in the mansion allowing you to go back in time at your will.

Dishonored 2 is an action-adventure game with stealth elements played from a first-person perspective.

132661163.review:
I recommend this game because in general it's very fun and has awesome gameplay. 
To make this review more objective, let's make a short summary with all the pros and cons.
Pros:
1. Awesome gameplay with a bunch of different ways to finish each task.
2. Good stylistic and overall technical part of the game. No major bugs as well.
3. Nice voice acting. The music is also pretty good.
4. Level design is decent, but there is a lot of space for improvement, the main issue here is that the locations are very repetitive, and mostly not so well detailed.
Cons:
1. AI could be better, all NPC's are not a threat to you in any difficulty except maybe "Iron Mode".
2. Story is complete and obsolete trash. It has a huge amount of loopholes and zero logic.
3. Chaos level system is too simple and does not work as it should, also I don't understand why it is required to play some "Absolutely good" role model without killing for example bandits or witches. Also, why do robots even count in this stat? Can't a good one be veracious and get rid of "bad guys" without a story/lore penalty?
4. The game stimulates the player to kill (while from a story perspective, it's bad), and a lot of loot is specifically for "high-chaos" gameplay, if you want to play mostly pacifist-like you'll have only:|
* Choking (Unaware or Counter-strike) 
* Tranquilizing bolt for the crossbow
* Throwing some objects in the head (with a specific perk)
I think a game like this needs much more non-lethal ways to eliminate guards and target itself, for example, as in the Hitman Trilogy.

The overall game is very amusing and could give you a nice pastime for a few evenings.
My subjective rate is 7 out of 10.
